Title: Trump's Bungled Bet On Bitcoin Is Costing Him Bigtime
Description:
ByDan Alexander,

Forbes Staff.

Donald Trump, the crypto skeptic-turned-‚Äúchief crypto advocate,‚Äù became one of the world's biggest bitcoin investors this summer, when his Trump Media and Technology Group purchased $2 billion of the cryptocurrency. On stage at a bitcoin conference in Las Vegas, one day after news of the plan became public, first son Donald Trump Jr. couldn't help but gloat. ‚ÄúI think you saw, all, the announcement yesterday,‚Äù he said, his voice rising like a politician anticipating applause. ‚ÄúWe're very long crypto. I mean, it's a huge part of everything that we do right now.‚Äù

The price of bitcoin had just jumped 57% in a year, and Don Jr. predicted it would increase about 35% to 60% more in the year to come. Next to him on stage, his brother Eric foresaw a 55% jump. A half year later, those calls look like signs of an overheated market. From the time Trump Media purchased its pile of bitcoin in July, the cryptocurrency is down an estimated 12%. The president, in turns out, got in at the top, or pretty close to it.

Volatility is inherent in crypto, as Donald Trump pointed out in 2019. ‚ÄúI am not a fan of Bitcoin and other Cryptocurrencies, which are not money, and whose value is highly volatile and based on thin air,‚Äù he tweeted at the time. Five years later, with crypto money pouring into the 2024 election, he changed his tone. ‚ÄúYou are the modern-day Edisons and Wright brothers and Carnegies and Henry Fords,‚Äù he told a gathering of bitcoin enthusiasts in Nashville.

As the price of bitcoin soared, the president's social-media business flailed. Truth Social, Trump Media's copycat of Twitter, never attracted as many users as the original. Its market debut in early 2024 nonetheless caught the imagination of meme-stock traders who liked the idea of a Trump-powered social-media app. Then Elon Musk purchased the real Twitter, reversed Trump's ban, and made the idea of a more-conservative Twitter seem pointless. Losses piled up at Trump Media, and shares tanked, declining 68% from their peak and erasing $3.3 billion from Trump's net worth by May.

Surely hoping to spawn another stock surge, Trump Media announced its bitcoin play that month, promising the president‚Äîwho now owns 41% of the shares‚Äîan indirect position in the cryptocurrency‚Äîroughly $830 million. Investors, perhaps wary after the company's struggles, didn't think much of the idea. Shares dropped 19% in three days, and Trump lost another $560 million.

At some point between July 1 and July 21‚Äîit's not clear exactly when‚ÄîTrump Media amassed its bitcoin stockpile, buying when the price was an estimated $115,000. It looked like a decent bet for a while, with bitcoin moving up and down in a relatively tight band. Then, over the last month, the cryptocurrency dropped 17%. Trump Media's bitcoin holdings, which cost $2 billion (on top of the $76 million required to gin up the capital to make the investment) are now worth an estimated $1.7 billion. Shares of Trump Media, which assumed about a billion dollars of debt in the process, fell 24%, wiping out $490 million of Trump's now-$6.7 billion personal fortune. A turnaround in bitcoin's price could send the stock‚Äîand the president's net worth‚Äîup again.

Amid the current troubles, Trump Media, which previously sued Forbes and other outlets for allegedly inaccurately reporting losses, is back to criticizing the press. "Only a fake news outlet like Forbes could look at Trump Media, which grew its financial assets from $274 million when we went public just a year and a half ago to more than $3 billion as reported in our last quarterly earnings, thanks in large part to our bitcoin treasury strategy, and conclude that the strategy failed," a Trump Media spokesperson said in a statement.

It's true that the bitcoin play increased Trump Media's assets. But simply buying stuff, particularly at high prices, does not necessarily make someone richer. And unfortunately for Trump Media, it is investors‚Äînot news outlets‚Äîwho have concluded the company is now worth about one-third of what it once was.

Title: 'If BTC Falls, So Does the Pentagon,' Eric Trump Says Bitcoin Will Be the Last Asset Standing in Global Meltdown
Description:
Trump lays out his case for why Bitcoin isn't just surviving, but destined to outlast everything. | Credit: Getty Images.                         

At the Blockchain Futurist Conference in Florida, Eric Trump spoke less like a politician and more like a man trying to make sense of a new world.

Standing before a room full of crypto founders, miners, and retail investors, he traced his own journey from skeptic to believer ‚Äî one that began, he said, just four or five years ago.

He talked about Bitcoin's (BTC) energy consumption, about inflation and hard assets, and what he sees as a broken financial system that keeps ordinary people locked out.

The tone was part curiosity, part conviction ‚Äî a glimpse into how the Trump family's younger son has found his footing in the crypto space.

On a stretch of Texas desert, a massive warehouse hums with electricity, 600 yards long, packed with thousands of computers mining Bitcoin. To Eric Trump, this industrial fortress isn't just a business; it's a revelation.

‚ÄúI was a guy who didn't understand this world until four or five years ago,‚Äù he admitted. ‚ÄúI've spent a lot of time studying it.‚Äù

That study, he says, changed everything.

He now believes the same energy that fuels these mining rigs also protects the future of finance.

‚ÄúIt [Trump's mining facility] uses about two and a half times the power of the city of White Plains,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúand it's protecting about 2.5% of the world's Bitcoin.‚Äù

Speaking on energy, Trump doubled down on Bitcoin with an argument that is as audacious as it is absolute.

The younger Trump claimed that Bitcoin's energy network is so vast that if it were to collapse, the rest of the digital world would fall with it.

‚ÄúIf Bitcoin went down ‚Äî congratulations, the Pentagon's gone,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúCongratulations, Amazon's gone. Congratulations, Google's gone. JPMorgan doesn't stand a chance.‚Äù

In his view, the energy that protects the Bitcoin network exceeds the defensive capacity of entire nations. ‚ÄúThe energy used to safeguard Bitcoin would be that of major, major countries around the world,‚Äù he said.

And if anyone thinks quantum computing could break it, Trump is unconvinced.

‚ÄúYou don't think that a quantum computer would have already taken out Bank of America? You don't think your Amazon account would already be gone?‚Äù he asked. ‚ÄúBitcoin would actually be the last in a series of entities to fall.‚Äù

For Trump, that resilience is proof not just of Bitcoin's security ‚Äî but of its permanence.

Ironically, Eric Trump admitted to the panel that he wasn't this ‚Äòlocked-in' into Bitcoin a few years ago, and neither were his friends.

‚ÄúWe believe in great assets, and great assets build great wealth,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI truly believe that Bitcoin's a great asset‚Äîthat's why I'm buying it.‚Äù

He recalled a friend in private wealth management who once dismissed crypto as ‚Äúfunny money.‚Äù

Eighteen months later, the same banker called back to say he was now recommending clients put ‚Äú2 to 5%‚Äù of their portfolios into Bitcoin.

To Trump, that's evidence the tide has turned. ‚ÄúWe're winning this race right now,‚Äù he told the crowd.

He compares crypto's current stage to the internet in 1999 ‚Äî still young, still misunderstood, but prepared for exponential growth.

Speaking on growth and permanence, in classic Trumpian fashion, he tied the argument to inflation and politics.

‚ÄúI think Biden did the greatest disservice to America of any president in history with his inflationary policies,‚Äù he said.

Those policies, he argued, only reward people ‚Äúwith hard assets‚Äù‚Äîowners of homes, steel, or Bitcoin‚Äîwhile crushing ‚Äúthe young guy, the young girl who just came out of school and is trying to build up the American dream.‚Äù

‚ÄúBitcoin is the solution to so much of it,‚Äù he declared.

For Trump, crypto represents a new path to financial self-reliance. A way for people without famous last names or hundreds of millions in collateral to access credit and opportunity.

‚ÄúYou have $100,000 in Bitcoin,‚Äù he said, ‚Äúyou can borrow 80% of it ‚Ä¶ You can buy your first home or start your first business.‚Äù That, he said, ‚Äúis financial freedom.‚Äù

‚ÄúGo to JPMorgan and try and do that,‚Äù he said of borrowing against assets. ‚ÄúGood luck‚Ä¶ unless you've got a last name like ours,‚Äù he quipped.

That imbalance, he argued, is what cryptocurrency can fix. ‚ÄúCrypto is financial freedom for the masses that never existed before and has only existed to a very select few.‚Äù

And he made clear who he's rooting against. ‚ÄúThere's no person in the world that wants to see this industry beat the big banks more than I do,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBitcoin's gonna lead the way.‚Äù

Eric Trump may not have his father's bombast, but his rhetoric channels the same populist chord‚Äîpitting ordinary Americans against entrenched power.

In his view, Bitcoin isn't just a digital asset; it's a rebellion against inflation, bureaucracy, and legacy finance itself.

‚ÄúWe're really on the front end of it,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI believe in it with every ounce of my soul.‚Äù

For Trump, the promise of crypto isn't about speculation‚Äîit's about access. A chance, as he put it, ‚Äúto live the American dream.‚Äù

Title: Bitcoin Has ‚ÄúSignificant Upside‚Äù to $170K, JPMorgan Tells Clients
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

JPMorgan analysts see Bitcoin climbing to approximately $170,000 within six to twelve months as perpetual futures deleveraging appears complete and the crypto's volatility ratio versus gold improves to more favorable levels.

Bitcoin currently trades near $101,000, down 1.6% in the past 24 hours.

The bank's strategists, led by Managing Director Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, noted in a Wednesday report that crypto markets corrected nearly 20% from recent peaks following record liquidations in perpetual futures on October 10, the largest in crypto history, followed by smaller liquidations on November 3, triggered by the $128 million Balancer exploit.

Despite consecutive selloffs, JPMorgan analysts concluded that the deleveraging phase in perpetual futures has largely come to an end.

The ratio of open interest in bitcoin perpetual futures to market capitalization fell from above-average levels back to historical norms within weeks, with similar patterns visible in Ethereum markets, though less pronounced there.

‚ÄúOverall, we believe that perpetual futures are the most important instruments to watch in the current juncture, and the message from the recent stabilization is that deleveraging in perpetual futures is likely behind us,‚Äù the analysts wrote.

They added that while exchange-traded funds saw modest redemptions recently, these paled compared with inflows during the weeks ending October 3 and October 10.

The analysts also observed opposite dynamics in CME futures, where Ethereum experienced more liquidations than Bitcoin futures.

Their analysis points to perpetual futures as the critical barometer for current market conditions rather than traditional futures or ETF flows.

Rising gold volatility has enhanced Bitcoin's appeal to investors on a risk-adjusted basis, according to JPMorgan's analysis.

The bitcoin-to-gold volatility ratio drifted below 2.0, implying Bitcoin currently consumes about 1.8 times more risk capital than gold.

Source: NewHedge

Based on this relationship, the analysts calculated that Bitcoin's current market capitalization of approximately $2.1 trillion would need to rise by nearly 67%.

This implies a theoretical price of around $170,000, to match the roughly $6.2 trillion in total private-sector investment in gold through ETFs and physical holdings.

Bitcoin currently trades about $68,000 below JPMorgan's volatility-adjusted fair value relative to gold.

‚ÄúThis mechanical exercise thus implies significant upside for bitcoin over the next 6-12 months,‚Äù the analysts stated.

The projection represents JPMorgan's latest in a series of bullish forecasts, following similar analyses in October that estimated potential upside toward $165,000 by year-end and August projections of $126,000, a level Bitcoin surpassed when it reached an all-time high above $126,200 on October 6.

Charles Schwab CEO Rick Wurster recently announced the $11.6 trillion firm will begin offering Bitcoin trading in the first half of 2026.

‚ÄúWe're having a lot of success in the crypto space,‚Äù Wurster said in a CNBC interview. ‚ÄúOur clients actually own 20% of them and our clients are coming to our research site 90% more than they were last year.‚Äù

Wurster explained that most investors prefer exchange-traded products as ‚Äúa safe and comfortable way for them to invest‚Äù rather than interacting directly with blockchain networks.

‚ÄúWe have lots of clients who have the vast majority of their assets at Schwab but are holding some at digitally native firms and keep asking us to launch this so they can bring their crypto assets to us,‚Äù he added.

Fundstrat Global Advisors' CIO, Tom Lee, has also recently characterized recent market weakness as liquidity-driven rather than fundamental.

‚ÄúThe bitcoin dip wasn't about fundamentals‚Äîit was liquidity plus shutdown plus funding stress plus the October 10th deleveraging,‚Äù Lee said, adding that confidence needs ‚Äúa couple more weeks to rebuild‚Äù but there's ‚Äúno systemic damage and no FTX-style contagion this time.‚Äú

Notably, Cathie Wood's Ark Invest has also recently lowered its most bullish Bitcoin forecast to $1.2 million by 2030 from $1.5 million, citing faster-than-expected stablecoin scaling.

However, Wood remains optimistic about Bitcoin's long-term trajectory, emphasizing growing institutional adoption and its role as a new global monetary system.

‚ÄúIt could at least be half‚Äù of gold's value, Wood said, noting institutions ‚Äúhave just dipped their toes into this space.‚Äú

Mexican billionaire Ricardo Salinas also predicted Bitcoin will rise eight times to over $1 million ‚Äúvery shortly‚Äù to match gold's $16 trillion private investment value.

‚ÄúBitcoin is a new global reserve asset. It will surpass gold,‚Äù Salinas stated, expressing ‚Äúno doubts that it will happen very shortly.‚Äú

Read original story Bitcoin Has "Significant Upside" to $170K, JPMorgan Tells Clients by Anas Hassan at Cryptonews.com

Title: Cathie Wood's Ark Invest Buys BitMine Ethereum Treasury Shares After Cutting Bitcoin Price Target
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

Ark Invest, the investment firm run by noted technology investor Cathie Wood, added 240,507 shares‚Äîaround $9.2 million worth‚Äîof Ethereum treasury firm BitMine Immersion Technologies (BMNR) via three of its actively managed ETFs on Thursday. 

The firm's latest acquisition comes amid a slide in BMNR shares as Ethereum continues to fall from its recently set all-time high. Shares of BMNR are up 2% on Friday, now changing hands above $38 as ETH trades at $3,375. 

Collectively, Ark's ARKK, ARKF, and ARKW ETFs now collectively hold more than 6.8 million shares of BMNR, valued at nearly $260 million. 

The firm made its biggest purchase of BMNR in July, adding around 4.7 million shares when it was trading around $40.77. At the time, BitMine Chairman Tom Lee called Wood's investment ‚Äúan exponential opportunity,‚Äù indicating that he was ‚Äúdelighted‚Äù at her firm's participation. 

BitMine now holds nearly 3.4 million ETH valued at almost $11.3 billion, making it the largest publicly traded Ethereum treasury firm and the second-largest publicly traded digital asset treasury, only trailing the Bitcoin-hoarding Strategy with its nearly $65 billion BTC stash.

Wood and her firm have been consistently bullish on digital assets and crypto equities, but on Thursday, she made headlines when she lowered a future Bitcoin price target.

Ark Invest's Cathie Wood Slashes Bitcoin Price Target Over Growing Stablecoin Mania

Previously, she predicted that the top crypto asset would reach $1.5 million per coin by 2030, but now she's cut her forecast to $1.2 million, citing rapid stablecoin adoption as a hindrance. 

"Given what's happening to stablecoins‚Äîserving emerging markets in the way we thought Bitcoin would‚ÄîI think we could take $300,000 off of that bullish case [for Bitcoin],‚Äù Wood said in an interview with CNBC on Thursday. 

The $1.2 million price target matches the ‚Äúbase case‚Äù provided by Wood's firm earlier this year when accounting for the ‚Äúactive supply‚Äù of Bitcoin‚Äîwhich discounts lost or long-held coins. In that report, the firm saw a bull case of $2.4 million per coin for BTC by 2030. 

Bitcoin is up 1.3% in the last 24 hours, now trading at $102,488. On Tuesday, the leading crypto asset dipped below $100,000 for the first time since May, and it again dipped below that mark early Friday. 

With its recent decline, predictors on Myriad no longer foresee the top crypto asset making a new all-time high again this year, giving odds of it happening just a 26% chance of doing so. 

Ethereum is up around 2.7% in the same time frame, now nearly 33% off its August all-time high of $4,946.

Title: Solana Flips Ethereum in Revenue Amid Price Meltdown
Description:
Solana SOLUSD has outperformed Solana in a key metric amid the ongoing market meltdown. According to data from DeFiLlama, Solana generated more app revenue than Solana in the past 24 hours and 30 days.

Solana leads in pp revenue

Solana flipped Ethereum to become the leading blockchain with the highest app-generated revenue. Per the DeFiLlama data, apps on Solana made $4.33 million in one day, while apps on Ethereum made only $1.82 million.

This is a huge flip, which no one saw coming, as Ethereum consistently took the lead. For instance, in Q1, 2024, Ethereum generated more app revenue than major public companies, including Robinhood, Etsy, Yelp and Reddit.

However, with the recent data, apps built on Solana accumulated more than twice the revenue of Ethereum. In addition, Hyperliquid also outperformed Ethereum, recording app revenue of $3.85 million.Blockchain Apps Per Revenue | Source: DeFiLlama">

Ethereum only outperformed blockchains like Edgex, Coinbase's Base, BSC, Polygon, Arbitrium, Aptos and Avalanche in the top 10. Edgex made $1.13 million in app revenue, Base amassed $980,504 and BSC accumulated $767,788.

App revenue is described as all the fees across every dApp in a blockchain. It is real money paid by users, and the best proof that people are actually using the chain.

The top Solana chains that contributed to the massive revenue are Pump.fun, Axiom Pro and Jupiter.

Why is Ethereum behind?

Solana flippening in app revenue comes amid the recent Ethereum price crash. Over the past 24 hours, the ETH price has decreased by 4.47% to $3,235. The leading altcoin is also down 15.94% and 27.7% over the past week and month, respectively.

Solana is also experiencing a similar downtrend. SOL is currently priced at $151.90, down 5.4% on the daily price chart. However, the app revenue spike could help spark optimism with the Solana network.

Revenue proves real usage. Thus, if apps keep earning money, validators get richer, staking APY rises, eventually leading to higher prices.

Overall, Solana has proved that it is faster, cheaper and makes more money than Ethereum even while prices drop.

The Solana exchange-traded funds (ETFs) also appeared to have sparked optimism within the ecosystem. Since launching, SOL ETFs have recorded inflows, indicating high demand from institutional investors.

This setup opens the door for a short-term bounce, possibly back toward the $3,900 level if bulls step in. But if that support cracks, Ethereum could accelerate downward ‚Äì and drag altcoins with it. The threat of a deeper pullback is real, and even meme traders are watching it closely.

Robert Kiyosaki is back with his usual warning: ‚ÄúMASSIVE CRASH BEGINNING.‚Äù He's told audiences that silver, gold, Bitcoin, and Ethereum are the assets to hold. 

But traders familiar with his past know he's posted over 30 crash warnings in the last 12 months ‚Äì many of which were followed by rallies, not collapses.

Still, this time around, Ethereum's chart is showing real weakness, and Kiyosaki's timing happens to align with the current breakdown risk.



If ETH fails to hold support, there's a real chance of a sharp move to the downside ‚Äì with $2,900 or even $2,500 in play. 

While some may dismiss Kiyosaki's words, the chart doesn't lie. And if this support breaks, the Ethereum price prediction narrative could flip fast from recovery to capitulation.

Title: Bitcoin and Ethereum ETFs See First November Inflows After $2.9 Billion Outflow Streak
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

Spot Bitcoin and Ethereum exchange-traded funds (ETFs) recorded their first net inflows for November 2025 on Thursday.

Bitcoin ETFs attracted $240 million, while Ethereum ETFs brought in $12.5 million. The turnaround follows six consecutive days of nearly $2.9 billion in combined outflows.

BeInCrypto reported recently that demand for spot ETFs had declined amid broader market weakness. This was evidenced by the consecutive outflows.

According to SoSo value data, between October 29 and November 5, Bitcoin ETFs recorded total outflows of approximately $2.05 billion. At the same time, investors pulled $837.66 million from Ethereum ETFs.

However, both products reversed this six-day run of outflows yesterday. Bitcoin ETFs saw $240.03 million in net inflows. The recovery was led by BlackRock's iShares Bitcoin Trust (IBIT), which attracted $112.44 million.

Fidelity Wise Origin Bitcoin Fund (FBTC) followed with $61.64 million, while ARK 21Shares Bitcoin ETF (ARKB) added $60.44 million. Bitwise's Bitcoin ETF (BITB) also contributed modestly with $5.5 million. Notably, no Bitcoin ETF reported outflows that day.

Spot Ethereum ETFs took in $12.51 million on November 6. BlackRock's iShares Ethereum Trust (ETHA) once again led the group with $8 million, trailed by Fidelity Ethereum Fund (FETH) with $4.95 million and Bitwise Ethereum ETF (ETHW) with $3.08 million.

Grayscale Ethereum Trust ETF (ETHE) recorded $3.53 million in outflows. The remaining five Ethereum funds reported no flows for the day.

The influx of capital has not done much to help the price. BeInCrypto Markets data showed that Bitcoin slipped 2.37% over the past day, extending its nearly 9% weekly decline. At the time of writing, the largest cryptocurrency traded at $100,768.

As the week draws to a close, analysts are closely monitoring the 50-week Exponential Moving Average (EMA-50) as a critical indicator for Bitcoin's next move.

"Everything depends on the weekly close. A weekly close above EMA-50 with strong buy volume means Bitcoin has bottomed. A weekly close below EMA-50 means the dump is just the beginning," analyst Ted Pillows wrote.

Meanwhile, Ethereum has also been trending downwards. Over the past week, the value of ETH has declined by around 15%. At press time, the altcoin's trading price stood at $3,284, down 3.40% over the past day.

"ETH is still hovering around the $3,300 level. If Ethereum loses the $3,100-$3,200 zone again, expect a correction to new monthly lows," Pillows forecasted.

As prices continue to face pressure, the coming weeks will be crucial in determining whether investors maintain their support through renewed ETF inflows or if further declines trigger another wave of selling across the crypto market.

Read original story Bitcoin and Ethereum ETFs See First November Inflows After $2.9 Billion Outflow Streak by Kamina Bashir at beincrypto.com

Title: 3 Altcoins To Watch This Weekend
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

The coming weekend is crucial for the crypto market as the fear of Bitcoin's price falling below $100,000 is intensifying. This makes altcoins dependent not on broader market cues but on their own network developments.

BeInCrypto has analysed three such altcoins that the investors should watch this weekend.

ICP has emerged as one of the top-performing altcoins this week after the launch of Dfinity's new AI tool, Caffeine. The no-language, AI-powered upgrade doubled the project's subnet capacity to 2 TiB, enhancing performance for HIPAA-compliant decentralized applications and driving stronger investor interest in the network's expanding AI ecosystem.

This surge in innovation fueled rapid demand, sending ICP's price soaring 166% within a week. Currently trading at $7.80, the altcoin has broken past the $7.61 resistance, reaching a 10-month high. If bullish sentiment holds, ICP could rally further toward the $10.83 mark, extending its strong upward trajectory into the weekend.

Want more token insights like this? Sign up for Editor Harsh Notariya's Daily Crypto Newsletter here.

However, if investors begin taking profits after the steep rally, selling pressure may intensify. This could cause ICP's price to decline to $6.05 or even lower to $4.67. A fall below these levels would invalidate the bullish outlook and erase much of the recent weekly gains.

Movement is preparing for a significant token unlock event in the next two days, with 50 million MOVE tokens worth over $2.90 million entering circulation. The sudden increase in supply amid subdued demand could amplify selling pressure.

The altcoin has been in a steady downtrend for the past month, and its strong 0.86 correlation with Bitcoin adds to market uncertainty. If MOVE follows Bitcoin's bearish trajectory, its price could drop below the $0.0525 support and potentially slip under $0.0461, extending recent losses and weakening investor sentiment.

However, renewed investor support could help reverse the trend. If buying pressure strengthens, MOVE could break the ongoing downtrend, pushing past the $0.0669 resistance and the $0.0741 barrier. A successful breach of these levels would invalidate the bearish thesis.

Another one of the altcoins to watch this weekend is AXS, which is preparing for a token unlock similar to MOVE, though on a smaller scale. The upcoming unlock, valued at just $854,780, is unlikely to significantly affect the altcoin's price. The limited supply inflow reduces the risk of heavy selling pressure, helping maintain short-term price stability.

Despite this, AXS has been stuck in a month-long downtrend that it could soon break. The MACD indicator is nearing a bullish crossover, signaling potential momentum reversal. If market sentiment improves, AXS could rise above the downtrend, surpassing $1.39 resistance and reaching $1.51 or higher in the coming sessions.

However, if bearish conditions persist, AXS could face renewed selling pressure. A decline below the $1.18 support may send the altcoin under $1.15, with a possible retest of $1.00. Such a move would invalidate the bullish thesis and extend losses for Axie Infinity investors.

Read original story 3 Altcoins To Watch This Weekend | November 8 ‚Äì 9 by Aaryamann Shrivastava at beincrypto.com

Title: Crypto Markets Today: Bitcoin (BTC) Defends $100K Price as Traders Flee Altcoins
Description:
The crypto market compounded a negative week with a continued drawdown on Friday. Bitcoin BTC$102,012.68 dropped to $100,600 and ether ETH$3,355.00 is languishing as $3,270.

The move appears to be in line with the wider crypto market trend of late, which has seen BTC lose 18% of its value over the past 30 days. Both the CoinDesk 5 Index (CD5) of the largest, most active tokens and the broader CoinDesk 20 Index (CD20) have lost about 3% in the past 24 hours.

The fallout can still be attributed to comments out of the Federal Reserve earlier in the week that suggested a potential cooling of the rate-cutting cycle, causing a rise in the U.S. dollar and a slump in risk assets.

The altcoin market, with the exception of AI tokens, is performing worse than bitcoin, with the "altcoin season" index at 22/100, its lowest in more than 90 days.

Title: Exclusive: Stripe-backed startup Tempo leads $25 million raise for crypto infrastructure firm Commonware
Description:
Ben Weiss is a crypto reporter at Fortune.

A high-profile project launched by fintech giant Stripe and crypto VC firm Paradigm has just made its first venture bet. On Friday, Tempo, a payments-focused blockchain, announced it's led a $25 million fundraise for the crypto infrastructure company Commonware. As part of the arrangement, the Stripe-backed project will work with Commonware to develop methods to process blockchain payments more quickly, Paradigm general partner and CTO Georgios Konstantopoulos said in a blog post.

Patrick O'Grady, founder of Commonware, declined to name other participants in the fundraise for his startup, which develops open-source code to allow others to launch their own blockchains. O'Grady also declined to disclose the valuation for his firm following the Tempo-led raise, but said it was a ‚Äúsignificant increase‚Äù over the valuation in Commonware's seed round, which Pitchbook reports as $63 million.





‚ÄúUsage and distribution is way more important than money as a startup,‚Äù he told Fortune. ‚ÄúIf we can short circuit that process and have a deep relationship, multi-year relationship, with a great team, instead of raising maybe a traditional round from a venture fund, that was the opportunity that Tempo presented.‚Äù





Tempo's investment into Commonware isn't its first splashy move since Stripe and Paradigm officially unveiled the project in September. The payments-focused blockchain company has acquired the crypto startup Ithaca and hired Dankrad Feist, a high-profile researcher who contributed to the development of the Ethereum blockchain. Tempo has also increased its headcount from around five employees in August to now between 40 and 50, according to a person familiar with the company, who spoke on the condition of anonymity to discuss private business information. 





It's rare for a startup to make an acquisition, a big hire, and significant investment so early on since it launched, but Tempo has the backing of some of the biggest names in tech and crypto. Stripe is a payments goliath that's worth more than $100 billion. Paradigm is one of the top venture capital firms in crypto. And Tempo's design partners include heavyweights like OpenAI, Anthropic, and Shopify.




The Stripe-linked startup also has a hefty war chest. It's raised $500 million at a $5 billion valuation from some of the top VCs in Silicon Valley, including Thrive Capital, Greenoaks, Sequoia, and Ribbit Capital, Fortune first reported. 





‚ÄúWe think that they're going to do just as good of a job, or better, showing off what Commonware can do than what we can do,‚Äù said O'Grady, the founder of Commonware, in reference to Tempo.





Founded in 2024, Commonware has only seven employees (including O'Grady) and four customers, but it's already profitable, he said. It makes money through helping companies deploy as well as interface with its open-source software, and each customer on average generates more than $1 million in annual revenue. ‚ÄúWe have now a bit of a backlog of people that want to work with us,‚Äù O'Grady added.

Title: The Next PayPal? How AI And Blockchain Are Rewriting Digital Payments
Description:
BySandy Carter,

Contributor.

For the last two decades that I've been paying online, PayPal has been my default.

Why? It's safe, easy, and fast.

But now that model is shifting. When you combine AI and blockchain, you get something entirely new: software or AI agents that act on our behalf, not just process a payment.

According to Boston Consulting Group (BCG), global payments revenue is expected to reach $2.4 trillion by 2029, with agentic AI, digital currencies and real-time payments shaping the change.

To show some of these shifts, I'd like to discuss three companies that I've had the chance to talk to recently. Bankr, Olas Pearl, and the fast-rising TON chat wallet ecosystem are all doing fascinating things in this space. 

Each one changes the game for online payments. 

I loved my conversation with Danielle Brown-Wolf, who leads growth at Bankr. She explained the simple goal of Bankr: to reach people where they already spend their time and solve one of the biggest pain points in crypto: accessibility.

Bankr is a conversational, onchain AI agent that lives at bankr.bot and is also accessible on X and Telegram. It turns your social handle into a wallet login, powered by Privy, and executes real transactions directly from chat. 

You can send a message like ‚ÄúBuy $100 of ETH‚Äù and the agent will process the transaction, bridge across chains if needed, and record everything transparently on the blockchain. Every interaction is verifiable and happens in real time.

This approach removes friction for everyday users who might not be familiar with decentralized wallets or seed phrases. 

Bankr lives where the audience already is.Deployer, the founder, of Bankr, told me that "AI agents will provide more financial opportunities to more people because they handle the complex part for you. Bankr is already doing this, analyzing the market and teaching people how to trade all through simple conversation."

On X and Telegram, your social handle becomes your wallet login. You type a simple instruction, and the agent executes it, with every transaction recorded on the blockchain.

I watched Bankr run technical analysis, place limit orders, settle a sports wager on Polymarket, and list an NFT on OpenSea, all from social feeds and a private terminal.

This is more than trading. It's a payments and value transfer layer that feels like a conversation.

Someone posts a pick for the game. A friend replies, ‚ÄúBankr, place 50 on the Eagles.‚Äù The action happens right there in public, and others can copy it with one reply. Groups that never thought of themselves as crypto users are suddenly moving money together because the wallet feels like chat, not finance.

The product focuses on safety and recovery. Accounts are non-custodial through Privy. Users can back up with email or sign in through Telegram or Farcaster if their X handle is suspended. Gas fees are covered. Links to Basecan give instant proof of what happened.

Bankr even turned a security feature with Blockaid into a live demo by asking the agent to buy a known fake token. The agent refused in public and explained why. 

That's how you build trust.

Danielle Brown Wolf, Head of Growth at Bankr, calls this ‚Äúthe PayPal moment for crypto.‚Äù  In our conversation, she said ‚ÄúBankr brings real payments into everyday conversations. When you can send or invest money as easily as you tweet, that's when digital finance finally becomes mainstream.‚Äù The analogy fits. 

PayPal made payments as simple as an email address. Bankr is doing the same with a social handle and an intelligent agent that can understand intent and act. It's software that lives where the customer already is.

I spoke with David Minarsch, the co-founder of Valory AG, the team behind the Olas network.

Their latest launch, Pearl v1, introduces a simple idea.  It's an AI agent marketplace.  According to Salesforce, by 2030, consumers will have personal AI agents acting on our behalf and will handle everything from planning our schedules to managing our finances.

People can browse, create, and launch autonomous agents on a decentralized platform that functions like a marketplace. They start by setting a goal and configuring what they want the agent to do. Once it's created, they can fund it with a card or wallet, and it operates independently while remaining fully under your control.

Every action the agent takes is recorded onchain, creating a complete and transparent history. Nothing runs behind closed servers, so your keys, data, and decisions stay private and secure. Because the agents live on a decentralized network rather than a single company's cloud, they continue to function even if part of the system goes offline.

In simple terms, it's a place where anyone can build and own AI-powered agents that work for them directly, without relying on centralized platforms.

Why does this matter for payments? Commerce is full of small but repetitive tasks that humans still perform by hand, like invoice matching, subscription updates, split payments, rewards, and fee management.

In chatting with David Minarsch, Cofounder of Valory, he told me that they ‚Äúsee a future where every individual can deploy their own on-chain AI agent.  And it will be one that manages money, data, and decisions transparently. The goal isn't to replace people; it's to empower them with digital teammates that they fully own.‚Äù 

Pearl gives developers a way to create specialized agents that execute those jobs from start to finish with verifiable results. It looks like an app store, but the apps are workers that move value according to clear rules you set.

One example, a DeFi trading agent named Modius, produced a strong return in just a few months and did it with full on-chain transparency.

The future is clear. 

As the catalog grows, many of these agents will go beyond trading. They'll handle payments, reconcile wallets, and streamline everyday financial tasks that still rely on email or manual approvals today.

The third space to watch is the TON wallet ecosystem inside Telegram. It pairs a massive user base with chat-native money.

Wallets live under the same keyboard people already use to message friends, brands, and creators. The next step is easy to imagine: intelligent agents that become the front door to payments inside those chats.

Think about a customer support bot that issues refunds after verifying an order, or a creator's bot that sells a digital good and automatically splits revenue among collaborators. A small business agent could invoice a group chat and divide the bill across multiple wallets.

None of this needs a checkout page. It all happens inside the conversation, with payments recorded on the blockchain and receipts visible to both sides.

TON's biggest advantage is scale, and Goodies shows why that matters.

Goodies is a Telegram mini app built on TON that blends collectibles, brands, and payments in one place. When I tried it, I watched sticker packs from Kung Fu Panda, Pudgy Penguins, and Lamborghini sell out in seconds. There's already a thriving secondary market for these stickers, where people buy and trade them directly inside Telegram.

In chatting with Luca Netz, the CEO of Pengu, he talked to about the strategy. ‚ÄúEmbedding brand Intellectural Property (IP) into daily habitual (GM) and conversational moments through memes and GIFs has been a strategy that we caught early on with Pudgy Penguins. Now with tokenization of stickers on Telegram, there's a new layer of ownership and expression unfolding.‚Äù

It feels like if NFTs and emojis had a baby, fun, social, and simple.

I had the chance to spend time with Danny Wheeler, Key Advisor at the Goodies Marketplace.  This was just after their amazing launch with Kung Fu Panda and Pudgy Penguins. He told me in that conversation that ‚Äúour goal is to build the world's first chat native economy. Every brand sticker, every collectible on TON, is proof that digital commerce can be instant, emotional, and transparent. When someone sends a sticker, they're not just sharing an emoji but they're sharing ownership and culture.‚Äù 

Each drop combines pop culture with blockchain in a way that feels natural and mainstream. You tap, pay, and own it. No setup. No friction. Just an experience that turns digital art into instant commerce.

This is what digital payments look like when AI, culture, and blockchain work together.

PayPal isn't standing still either. The company has been quietly reinventing itself for the new digital era, experimenting with stablecoins, AI-driven fraud detection, and blockchain infrastructure to stay relevant in a world moving toward decentralized finance. 

Its launch of PayPal USD (PYUSD) marked one of the first times a major payments provider issued its own fully backed stablecoin, signaling that even legacy platforms see the shift coming. 

PayPal is also expanding into new areas of cross-border payments, merchant automation, and crypto accessibility, working to stay the default for both traditional users and the next generation of digital wallets.

What I saw at their Developer Days was also an impressive vision of where AI Agents are heading.  Their vision shows even established leaders are thinking about autonomy, personalization, and intelligence inside payments.

All three of these companies share the same pattern.

They meet users where they already are. They turn plain language into secure actions. They keep ownership and transparency with the user. They hide the crypto complexity but preserve trust and control.

Bankr shows how conversational wallets can turn social feeds into payment hubs. Pearl shows how agent stores can automate financial workflows. TON and Goodies show how chat and culture can merge into a new kind of payment experience.

Cards and banks will still exist, but more payments will start and finish inside conversations, managed by agents people can trust and verify.

That's the part that feels like the next PayPal. Not a new button on a checkout page, but a new way the internet moves money.

Title: Ripple drives growth in the blockchain ecosystem with institutional-grade security measures
Description:
The digital asset infrastructure provider brings enhanced self-custody technology to financial firms in the Asia-Pacific region

Blockchain technology and digital assets, including cryptocurrency, are already moving beyond their initial limitations as niche technologies to shape a more accessible, secure and impactful ecosystem. Ninety per cent of finance leaders believe these technologies will have a profound effect on the industry within three years, according to a recent survey conducted by Ripple, a digital asset infrastructure company.

As compelling use cases emerge ‚Äì from cross-border payments to tokenisation of real-world assets ‚Äì the first challenge any firm must address is safe and secure custody. The institutional adoption of blockchain technology hinges on the ability to store, access and protect digital assets with confidence.

‚ÄúThe next wave of growth in digital assets won't be driven by retail speculation; it will be driven by institutional utility ‚Äì and the foundation for that is secure custody,‚Äù says Jack Cullinane, Ripple's senior director, commercial, Asia-Pacific. ‚ÄúIn hubs like Hong Kong, regulatory clarity is accelerating the move for institutions to enter this space.‚Äù

Across the world's financial hubs, including Hong Kong, regulators are moving to support these new technologies by ensuring that sophisticated, institutional-grade infrastructure is balanced with robust regulatory compliance for seamless, 24-hour-a-day usability. The city's Securities and Futures Commission's rules on digital asset custody ensure institutions manage assets in line with standards seen in traditional finance, reflecting the growing market need for secure, compliant infrastructure to support exchange-traded funds, tokenised funds, stablecoin settlement and cross-border treasury and liquidity solutions.

Secure crypto custody is critical to the global financial ecosystem. Ripple Custody provides the essential institutional-grade platform for securing, transferring and settling any class of tokenised financial assets. Ripple delivers the self-custody technology layer that enables banks and financial institutions to manage digital assets without compromising their existing security.

Title: An innovative blockchain framework for strengthening security and efficiency in banking
Description:
Thank you for visiting nature.com. You are using a browser version with limited support for CSS. To obtain
            the best experience, we recommend you use a more up to date browser (or turn off compatibility mode in
            Internet Explorer). In the meantime, to ensure continued support, we are displaying the site without styles
            and JavaScript.

Advertisement


Scientific Reports
volume 15, Article number: 39029 (2025)
            Cite this article


Blockchain technology is revolutionizing industries by fundamentally transforming data management and storage practices. Traditional banking systems, however, continue to face challenges such as dependency on intermediaries, lack of transparency, vulnerability to fraud, and restricted accessibility. To overcome this limitation, we propose an innovative blockchain framework built on the Ethereum platform to enhance security and efficiency in banking. The proposed system eliminates intermediaries by using Ethereum-based smart contracts to enable secure, automated peer-to-peer (P2P) deposits, withdrawals, and transfers while incorporating a user-friendly interface with MetaMask and custom wallets for accessibility. The architecture was implemented and tested on the Sepolia Ethereum Testnet using Solidity, Ether.js, and React.js, ensuring seamless interaction between the smart contract and the user interface. Our experimental evaluation demonstrated significant improvements in transaction speed, transparency, and operational efficiency compared to traditional systems, with near real-time processing and automated verification. Performance benchmarking showed competitive latency and throughput, while gas cost analysis highlighted trade-offs in transaction expenses compared to conventional banking. These findings suggest that our blockchain framework has strong potential to address long-standing inefficiencies in the financial sector. While challenges remain, including scalability and regulatory considerations, this work offers a concrete and impactful step toward the practical adoption of blockchain in mainstream banking.

The financial landscape is undergoing a significant transformation driven by the emergence of innovative technologies. Among these, Blockchain technology stands out for its potential to revolutionize how we conduct Banking and Mobile payments1. This paper explores blockchain integration into these critical financial processes, proposing a blockchain-based approach for achieving greater efficiency and security.

Traditional Banking systems, while well-established, often need to be improved. Transaction speeds can be sluggish and hampered by centralized infrastructures and intermediary institutions. Transparency can be limited, with users often needing more clear visibility into transaction details and fees. Costs associated with cross-border payments can be high, further burdened by complex regulations and exchange rates. Mobile payments, on the other hand, offer undeniable convenience. However, concerns regarding data security and fraud prevention persist. Specifically, centralized data storage creates single points of failure, making systems vulnerable to large-scale data breaches, insider threats, and denial-of-service attacks. Centralized control of user data creates potential vulnerabilities, and disputes can be cumbersome to resolve within traditional mobile payment frameworks2,3,4.

Blockchain technology, with its core principles of decentralization, immutability, and cryptography, offers a compelling solution to address these challenges. It fosters a distributed ledger system, eliminating the need for centralized control and intermediaries. This translates to faster transaction processing, with data securely stored across a network of computers, making it tamper-proof and auditable by all participants. Additionally, blockchain significantly reduces the reliance on traditional third-party verification, streamlining processes and potentially reducing costs associated with cross-border transactions.

This paper embarks on a comprehensive exploration of blockchain technology, delving into its core functionalities and specific applications within the banking and mobile payment domains2,1. We will dissect how blockchain can streamline transaction processing by removing intermediaries and enabling expedited settlements. We will explore how its inherent cryptographic security safeguards user data and financial information, mitigating fraud risks. Furthermore, we will examine how blockchain fosters transparency by providing a shared, immutable record of all transactions,accessible to authorized participants.

The potential benefits extend far beyond technological advancements. We will analyze how a blockchain-based approach empowers financial institutions to streamline operations, reduce costs, and offer innovative financial products. For end-users, the advantages translate to faster, more secure, and potentially lower-cost transactions and greater control over their financial data.3,4

By meticulously examining the opportunities and challenges associated with blockchain integration, this paper aims to contribute significantly to the ongoing discourse on the future of secure and efficient banking and mobile payments. We will not only illuminate the transformative potential of this technology but also provide a critical analysis of the hurdles that need to be overcome for widespread adoption. These hurdles include regulatory uncertainty, scalability limitations regarding transaction throughput, interoperability challenges with existing legacy financial systems, user education requirements, and the complexities of private key management. Ultimately, this paper seeks to pave the way for a future where blockchain technology becomes the cornerstone of a secure, efficient, and inclusive financial ecosystem.

Our system leverages the capabilities of Ethereum to offer a suite of financial functionalities, including:

Account creation via metamask or custom wallet Users can create an account either through Metamask, a well-known cryptocurrency wallet, or a custom wallet designed for specific needs. Metamask simplifies interaction with Ethereum-based decentralized applications, while a custom wallet offers more tailored control and flexibility.

Deposit ether into the smart contract After account creation, users can deposit Ether (ETH) into a designated smart contract. The deposit process is secure and recorded immutably on the blockchain. The smart contract registers the transaction and makes the deposited Ether available for future interactions like withdrawals or transfers.

Withdraw ether from the smart contract Users can request to withdraw their Ether from the smart contract at any time, following the conditions set by the contract. The system verifies the withdrawal request, ensuring sufficient funds are available before securely transferring the Ether back to the user's connected wallet.

Transfer ether from one user account to another The platform also supports Ether transfers between user accounts. These peer-to-peer transactions are processed through the smart contract, ensuring that the sender has sufficient funds before completing the transfer. This system ensures security and transparency, leveraging the decentralized nature of blockchain technology to execute transactions without intermediaries.

This demonstrates the real-world applicability of blockchain technology within the realm of financial services. Other features could also be easily included in the system, but we will demonstrate our system with the three basic functions required for a transaction.

Blockchain technology is a secure, immutable, and distributed ledger system that addresses common issues in traditional transaction systems, including data security, transaction speed, and confidentiality5. Ashish Kumar Jha et al.2 discuss the integration of blockchain with platforms like banks and e-commerce sites to facilitate swift and secure transactions. While they highlight the benefits, their work lacks detailed implementation strategies, a gap our paper aims to address by providing a concrete system architecture and functional prototype.

A blockchain network consists of user nodes for clients and verification nodes managed by banks, as noted by6. This distributed setup enables verification nodes to validate transactions, confirm accounts, and generate blocks containing multiple transactions. Clients use user nodes to access account histories and initiate transactions. However, managing the complexity of multiple node types and ensuring their seamless interoperability in a large-scale banking environment presents significant challenges not fully explored in their conceptual model.

Additionally, Hamburger et al1 illustrates how a single database can simplify the KYC (Know Your Customer) process across banks through blockchain technology, thereby expediting transaction timelines for users sending money worldwide. Eliminating intermediaries further enhances transaction speed7,8,9. This approach is promising for reducing administrative overhead, but it necessitates extensive collaboration with regulatory bodies and may encounter legal hurdles related to data privacy and cross-border data sharing.

Blockchain also secures banking transactions without the need for tokens, effectively addressing challenges like node, media, and communication failures, developed by Seymour et al.10. Banks would manage all transactions directly, generating new blocks linked to the blockchain. A potential limitation of this method is the performance implications and scalability issues that might arise from block generation without the incentivization of miners, which could impact network throughput.

Mohamed1 proposed a blockchain-based architecture for secure mobile payments, highlighting the necessity for secure applications. Yi-Wei Chang et al.11 developed a decentralized e-marketplace platform that documents each transaction step on the blockchain, providing electronic proof in case of disputes. While innovative, the generalizability of their framework to diverse mobile payment systems remains uncertain, and its implementation may require extensive changes to existing marketplace infrastructures. Furthermore, research on blockchain frameworks has resulted in a proposed electronic voting system that tackles existing system shortcomings12. Despite its potential for enhanced integrity, voter privacy and overall system integrity may still be concerns that require robust cryptographic solutions beyond basic blockchain implementation. It is also worth noting that various consensus algorithms beyond Ethereum's Proof of Stake, such as Proof of Authority (PoA) or Delegated Proof of Stake (DPoS), offer different trade-offs in terms of decentralization, scalability, and energy consumption, which could be explored for specific banking applications.

Summary of Related Works on Blockchain Technology is presented in Table  1

Table  2 highlights key issues in current banking systems, including centralization leading to inefficiency, high transaction fees and latency causing financial losses, and data vulnerability, which raises concerns about theft and falsification. Centralization in traditional banking creates bottlenecks, single points of failure, and slow reconciliation processes, directly impacting efficiency and increasing operational costs. These challenges emphasize the need for improvements in security, efficiency, and trust within the banking sector. High transaction fees, particularly for cross-border payments, coupled with long wait times, result in significant financial losses for both institutions and customers, hindering liquidity and economic activity. Furthermore, the inherent lack of tamper-proof mechanisms in traditional banking data makes it susceptible to alteration without proper oversight, leading to concerns about fraud, theft, and falsification of records.

Blockchain technology can simplify transactions by doing away with the need for middlemen like clearinghouses. This has the potential to save expenses for banks as well as clients by greatly accelerating the processing of transactions. The primary driving force behind blockchain technology is the need for decentralization, which is accomplished by allocating compute duties to each blockchain network node. One of the issues with traditional systems that decentralization addresses is the single point of failure. Decentralization also fosters censorship resistance and enhances financial inclusion by lowering barriers to entry for unbanked populations. The fundamental technology of blockchain generates an unchangeable transaction record. By making it extremely impossible to change or modify financial data, this can increase security. However, it is important to acknowledge that while decentralization offers significant advantages, it also introduces complexities related to regulatory compliance and governance.

The main and summarised objectives of our method are as follows:

Enhance transparency and security Leverage blockchain technology to ensure immutable transaction records, fostering user trust and enabling independent verification of all financial activities within the banking system. This specifically aims to establish a cryptographically secured and auditable financial ledger, fundamentally transforming how trust is established and maintained.

Streamline user experience Develop intuitive interfaces and features like Metamask integration to facilitate seamless navigation and management of digital assets for all users.

Expand functional capabilities Incorporate mobile payment systems, third-party logins, and account creation features to enhance accessibility and support diverse transaction needs within the evolving cashless economy.

System architecture of the proposed blockchain framework.

The proposed framework built on two fundamental systems: one is the backend which manages Smart Contract activities and the user interface (UI) which interacts with the Smart Contract to carry out user actions.

Our system is built on using the Ethereum blockchain which is a decentralized blockchain with smart contract functionality. Ethereum provides a decentralized, public ledger system perfectly suited for secure and transparent financial transactions. Transactions are immutable and auditable by all participants, fostering trust and eliminating the need for centralized intermediaries. Ether is the native cryptocurrency of the platform. Among cryptocurrencies, ether is second only to bitcoin in market capitalization. It is open-source software.

Our smart contract is written using the solidity programming language. Solidity is a high-level, object-oriented programming language specifically created for writing smart contracts on the Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM). Ensuring the security of smart contracts is crucial in the realm of blockchain technology.

Smart contracts are immutable and self-executing codes essential for various decentralized applications and financial transactions. Smart contracts cannot be changed once they are deployed on the blockchain, in contrast to traditional software. Because of this immutability, extensive testing is more essential than ever. We are using the Chai assertion library to test out the contract. We perform unit testing and staging to ensure smart contracts work as intended without unexpected behavior or errors.

Deployment of a smart contract to any blockchain network is the most challenging part using a local development environment. That's why we use Hardhat which is an Ethereum Development Environment.

Hardhat facilitates the deployment of smart contracts to various blockchain networks, including Hardhat's own local network for testing purposes. This allows you to thoroughly test your contracts in a safe and controlled environment before deploying them. After that, we deploy out smart contract into the Seploia Testnet which is a public test network for the Ethereum blockchain. The Sepolia Testnet provides a safe and cost-effective environment to thoroughly test and debug our smart contracts before deploying them on the Ethereum mainnet. This mitigates risks and ensures a smooth user experience.

Deploying a smart contract to any blockchain network requires gas fees, which are necessary to execute transactions on the network. To cover these gas fees, we typically need a cryptocurrency wallet that holds the native token of the blockchain network. We are using Metamask crypto wallet. This wallet allows to sign transactions and pay for the computational resources required for deploying and interacting with smart contracts.

After completing the development of a smart contract, the next step is integrating it into a web application to enable user interaction. For the frontend development of the web application, we use React js which is a popular JavaScript library for building user interfaces. React.js was chosen for its component-based architecture, declarative programming style, and large, active community, which collectively enable the development of highly modular, reusable, and maintainable UI components. React.js enables us to create a user friendly and responsive web application for interacting with our financial functionalities. By leveraging React's component-based architecture, we can ensure a modular and maintainable codebase.

To connect our web application with the smart contract deployed on the Ethereum blockchain, we utilize a Web4-compatible library such as Ethers.js. Ethers.js was selected over alternatives like Web3.js due to its lighter footprint, improved type safety, built-in support for Ethereum Name Service (ENS), and a more streamlined Application Binary Interface (ABI) handling, which collectively enhance security and development efficiency. It simplifies complex blockchain operations like sending transactions, receiving transaction details, and managing accounts. This allows us to develop our user interface components in React.js while seamlessly integrating with the underlying Ethereum blockchain functionality.

The system architecture, as depicted in Fig.  1, operates by having the User Interface (UI) capture user inputs for financial transactions (e.g., deposit, withdrawal, transfer). These inputs are then transmitted via Ethers.js to the deployed smart contract on the Ethereum network. The smart contract, acting as the backend logic, processes these requests, updates the ledger state, and records the immutable transaction details on the blockchain. Metamask or the custom wallet facilitates the signing of these transactions, ensuring user authentication and authorization. Data, such as account balances and transaction histories, is primarily managed by the smart contract's state variables and recorded as events on the blockchain, which the UI can then query and display to the user.

The proposed blockchain-based framework relies on Ethereum smart contracts for executing core financial operations, including account creation, deposits, withdrawals, and peer-to-peer transfers. Each of these processes can be analyzed in terms of computational and time complexity. We incorporates three key algorithms: Ethereum account generation, Ether deposit, and Ether withdrawal with complex validation. Their computational and time complexities are analyzed as follows:

This algorithm performs key derivation, public key generation, hashing, and address extraction. Each step operates on fixed-size inputs, leading to constant complexity. The heaviest operation is elliptic curve point multiplication in ECDSA, which remains constant time for fixed key sizes13.

Execution time is negligible (milliseconds), independent of the number of users.

The deposit process involves transaction creation, signature verification, balance check, and broadcasting to the Ethereum network. All operations are constant time:

In our prototype, execution time is not limited by computational steps, but primarily by block confirmation latency inherent to Ethereum's consensus mechanism. On the Sepolia testnet, deposits confirm within 12‚Äì16 seconds on average, while Ethereum mainnet confirmation requires 12‚Äì25 seconds depending on congestion14,15.

The withdrawal process executes balance verification, withdrawal limit checks, timing constraints, balance update, and transfer. Each step is constant time, yielding:

As with deposits, actual execution time is determined by consensus latency and network throughput rather than algorithmic growth. Ethereum Layer 1 throughput is typically 15‚Äì30 TPS, while Layer 2 solutions can scale to thousands of TPS16.

Each transaction executes in constant time. For n transactions processed sequentially, the overall computational complexity is linear:

Practical performance is further influenced by blockchain characteristics such as throughput, consensus latency, and gas consumption. Gas cost analysis reinforces constant complexity, as deposits, withdrawals, and transfers consumed stable gas units (78,364; 61,207; and 41,667 respectively), regardless of input size13. By contrast, traditional banking settlements involve multiple intermediaries (correspondent banks, clearing houses), creating multi-step verification and reconciliation processes that may extend settlement to 2‚Äì3 business days17,18.

The proposed framework introduces several technical innovations in its design that strengthen both efficiency and security of banking settlements:

Smart contract‚Äìbased settlement All banking operations such as deposits, withdrawals, and transfers are executed by Ethereum smart contracts. This ensures deterministic execution, immutability, and transparency, reducing dependency on multiple intermediaries in traditional banking.

Gas-efficient contract design The smart contract functions were structured to minimize redundant computations, thereby lowering gas costs while maintaining correctness. This enhances scalability and cost predictability for high-volume financial transactions.

Wallet-centric user custody By integrating MetaMask and custom wallets, users retain full control of their private keys and assets. Unlike conventional systems where banks act as sole custodians, this design significantly reduces risks of centralized fraud or mismanagement.

Direct frontend‚Äìblockchain integration The use of Ether.js in the React.js interface allows seamless communication with Ethereum smart contracts. This bypasses centralized servers, ensuring that user interactions are securely and directly recorded on-chain.

Consensus-level security By building on the Ethereum network, the framework inherits strong distributed consensus guarantees. These provide fault tolerance, immutability, and protection against fraudulent or conflicting transactions, ensuring secure and reliable financial settlements.

These innovations distinguish the proposed approach from prior blockchain applications in banking3,5,6. The quantitative evaluation of these design choices, including gas efficiency, transaction latency, and settlement speed, is presented in the Outcome and Result Analysis section.

To situate our framework within prior research, we compared it against representative blockchain-based banking studies. Joseph and Karunan5 proposed a decentralized settlement system but without wallet-level integration or gas optimization. Muneeb et al.6 developed SmartCon, focusing on scalability, though lacking testbed validation on Ethereum. Bagrecha et al.3 outlined blockchain's potential in banking but presented only a conceptual model without complexity or latency analysis.

In contrast, the present work contributes:

Gas-optimized smart contracts validated on the Ethereum Sepolia Testnet with real gas benchmarks.

Seamless wallet integration (MetaMask/custom) ensuring user custody of funds.

Direct frontend‚Äìblockchain interaction through Ether.js, removing centralized servers.

Our proposed blockchain-based approach system as depicts on Fig.  2, uses the Ethereum blockchain and Ether (ETH) as the native currency to achieve unparalleled efficiency and security within these critical financial processes. Our system leverages the capabilities of Ethereum to offer a core set of financial functionalities built upon the Ethereum blockchain. These functionalities include:

New user accounts are created on the Ethereum blockchain. This generates a unique Ethereum address for each user, acting as their public identifier and the destination for deposits and transactions. User can create accounts in two different ways. (1) Our Own wallet or (2) Using user Existing account on the Metamask wallet

This is a summary of how our wallet creates a user account in Ethereum, starting with a seed phrase , then a private key, then a public key, and finally generate address:

A seed phrase is a collection of words that serves as a private key; it can also be referred to as a mnemonic phrase. It's a method of encoding a private key so that people may more easily recall and record it.

A key derivation function (KDF) like BIP32 or BIP39 can be used to create a private key from a seed phrase. These functions take a seed phrase and other input parameters and use a mathematical procedure to create a private key.

After obtaining a private key, you can create a public key using it. The Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA), is used to generate a 64-byte (or 512-bit) value from a private key in Ethereum.

Using the Keccak-256 hash function to extract a 20-byte (or 160-bit) value from a public key and use that value to construct an Ethereum address. The Ethereum address is this value, which is used to determine who owns the address.

User can also use their existing account on the Metamask wallet to create account into our system.

Ethereum Account Generation from Seed Phrase

Ether (ETH) Deposit Process

Users can deposit Ether (ETH) into their accounts. This process involves initiating a transaction on the Ethereum network and sending ETH from an external source (like a crypto exchange) to the user's Ethereum address.

Once initiated, the transaction is broadcasted to the Ethereum network, where it enters the mempool (a queue of pending transactions). Miners or validators on the network then select the transaction from the mempool, validate it by verifying the digital signature and the sender's account balance, and finally, include it in a new block. It is permanently recorded on the blockchain, a public and immutable ledger. This ensures the transaction cannot be altered or reversed, providing security and transparency.

The user can monitor the transaction status in real time by using blockchain explorers like Etherscan, which track the progress of transactions on the Ethereum network. These explorers allow users to enter their transaction hash (a unique identifier for the transaction) to view detailed information, including the number of confirmations received, the gas fee paid, and the current status (pending, confirmed, or failed).

Figure (a) Meta mask creation, (b) Deposit Ether Diagram, (c) Withdraw-amount-diagram, (d) Transfer-ether-diagram.

Users can withdraw Ether (ETH) from their accounts by initiating a transaction on the Ethereum network. This process involves specifying the recipient's Ethereum address and the amount of ETH to be transferred. Once the withdrawal request is made, the transaction is broadcasted to the Ethereum network, where it enters the mempool for processing.

Similar to deposits, smart contracts validate and secure the transaction on the blockchain during a withdrawal. When a user initiates a withdrawal, the smart contract governing the account automatically verifies several key aspects of the transaction. This includes ensuring the user has sufficient ETH in their account to cover the withdrawal, and checking that the transaction adheres to any predefined rules or conditions set by the platform, such as withdrawal limits or timing constraints.

ETH Withdrawal on Ethereum Network with Complex Validation

Users can transfer Ether (ETH) to other accounts on the Ethereum network, by utilizing the blockchain's core transfer capabilities. Users initiate a transaction by specifying the recipient's address and the amount of ether to be sent. The Ethereum network validates and secures these transfers through its consensus mechanism, ensuring that transactions are transparent, immutable, and resistant to tampering.

By enabling seamless and efficient ETH transfers, Ethereum showcases its potential to serve as a foundation for a secure and transparent decentralized banking system, where users have full control over their funds without relying on intermediaries.

These core functionalities demonstrate the potential of Ethereum to build a secure and transparent banking system. Throughout this paper, we will dive deeper into the technical aspects of how these functionalities are implemented on the Ethereum blockchain, exploring the benefits and challenges associated with such an approach.

Using blockchain technology, our proposed system combines user-friendly interfaces for smooth operation with transparent and impenetrable financial transactions. This project successfully developed a prototype for a blockchain-based banking system utilizing Etherjs, Reactjs, and Solidity. The key achievements include:

A user-friendly Reactjs online application enables peer-to-peer transfers as depicts on Figs.  3 and   4, account creation, and balance viewing. Etherjs enables smooth communication between these functionalities and the blockchain. The prototype successfully demonstrated near-real-time transaction processing for deposits, withdrawals, and transfers on the Sepolia testnet, with average transaction finality observed within seconds, reflecting the efficiency gains of a blockchain-based approach.

Peer-to-peer architecture.

Smart contracts automate transaction processing and account administration and those are two essential banking functions. This fosters security and trust by doing away with the necessity for a central authority. The implemented smart contracts, comprising approximately 500 lines of Solidity code, encapsulate core banking logic for managing user balances, processing transfers, and handling withdrawal requests. Their modular design facilitated independent testing of functions like ‚Äòfund()‚Äò, ‚Äòwithdraw()‚Äò, and ‚ÄòtransferEther()‚Äò, ensuring robust and predictable behavior. Challenges encountered during development primarily involved gas optimization and ensuring reentrancy protection, which were addressed through careful code structuring and adherence to best practices. Metamask integration.

The main transaction process of the system is illustrated in Fig.  8. To transfer funds to another user, the initial step for a user is to create an account. Once they have acquired the necessary amount of ether, their account will be established, allowing them to initiate transfers. After entering the desired transfer amount, the user can proceed.
