Title: Beloved Actress Passes Away & Fans Flood Social Media With Tributes
Description:
Oscar-nominated actress Pauline Collins, best known for her role in Shirley Valentine, has sadly passed away. She also appeared in films such as ‚ÄúQuartet‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger.‚Äù The beloved British actress passed away at the age of 85. 

According to the British Broadcasting Corporation, Collins passed away ‚Äúpeacefully‚Äù at her home in London in the presence of her family. Her death came after a years-long battle with Parkinson's disease. Collins leaves behind four children and her husband, John Alderton.

Collins appeared in over 70 roles throughout her legendary career. It's for this reason that many fans are flocking to social media to remember the screen legend. One person on X wrote, ‚ÄúThanks for everything, Pauline Collins. Your quiet talent shone out no matter what the job. RIP‚Äù

Another person said on X, ‚ÄúAlways guaranteed to light up the screen, either big or small, Pauline Collins has sadly left us. RIP.‚Äù

Someone else expressed their disbelief, saying, ‚ÄúOh, it can't be true!! Shirley Valentine is my all-time favourite film, I must've seen it a million times. I'm so, so gutted and sad about this. Rest in peace, Pauline Collins. Shirley and Joe reunited üòî‚Äù

Another fan wrote, ‚ÄúSad to hear we've lost Pauline Collins. A cracking actress. RIP‚Äù A Different fan stated, ‚ÄúRIP the wonderful, funny Pauline Collins. From Upstairs Downstairs to Mrs Caldicot's Cabbages via Shirley Valentine, she never failed to entertain in her own unique style.‚Äù

The social media tributes continued as someone else said, ‚ÄúOne of my favourite actors ‚Äì started watching Upstairs Downstairs again on ITVx. She was brilliant in everything she did. RIP Pauline Collins. #PaulineCollins‚Äù

Finally, another fan of her work wrote, ‚ÄúRIP Pauline Collins. She was magnificent in Upstairs Downstairs as the fiesty yet vulnerable Sarah, done wrong by that Master James and tragically losing her baby on the night the King came for dinner. Wonderful memories‚Ä¶üíî‚Äù

According to IMDb, Collins began her on-screen career in 1963 with episodic appearances in ‚ÄúEmergency-Ward 10‚Äù and ‚Äú24-Hour Call.‚Äù From there, she appeared in shows like ‚ÄúPardon the Expression,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Three Musketeers,‚Äù and ‚ÄúDr. Who.‚Äù

What most would call her big break came when she starred in ‚ÄúShirley Valentine‚Äù in 1989. This is the film that led to her Oscar nomination and Golden Globe and BAFTA wins. Her most recent role was in the 2017 film ‚ÄúThe Time of Their Lives.‚Äù Collins will be missed, but her legacy will live on. 

I'm sorry but who the heck is she again. Why are there so many people passing away lately that no one has heard of. This actress whoever she is, is like the nineth or tenth celebrity in a month that's passed away and no one has heard of them?

Title: Demi Moore Steps Out to Support Ex Bruce Willis Amid His Ongoing Dementia Battle
Description:
Demi Moore is honoring her ex-husband, Bruce Willis, in a heartfelt way that moved fans and friends alike. The Daily Mail reported that the 61-year-old actress attended a special gala in New York City on Wednesday, November 5, dedicated to raising awareness and funds for frontotemporal dementia, the condition Willis has bravely been battling since 2023.

The event, hosted by Soho Sessions in partnership with The Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration, was held ‚Äúin celebration of our friend Bruce Willis,‚Äù according to the official flyer shared by Daily Mail. Moore was joined by Willis' wife, Emma Heming Willis, who has become a strong advocate for dementia awareness and caregiving since his diagnosis.

The night drew an outpouring of love and support for the ‚ÄúDie Hard‚Äù star, with celebrity guests including Kevin Bacon, Kyra Sedgwick, Whoopi Goldberg, and Michael J. Fox in attendance.

Moore and Heming Willis, who have worked together to support Bruce's health journey, shared the evening in solidarity. Since Willis's diagnosis, the two women have often been seen publicly supporting each other, united in ensuring the actor's care and comfort.

Moore and Willis, who divorced in 1998, have remained close friends and co-parents to their three daughters, Rumer, Scout, and Tallulah. Their blended family has long been admired for its mutual respect and harmony.

During a recent appearance on The Oprah Podcast, Moore opened up about Heming Willis' strength in caring for Bruce.

‚ÄúI have so much compassion for Emma in this, being a young woman,‚Äù Moore said. ‚ÄúThere's no way that anybody could have anticipated where this was going to go. And I really think she's done a masterful job. She has been so dedicated to forging the right path. She's had equal amounts of fear and strength and courage in navigating this.‚Äù

Moore continued, ‚ÄúIt's hard to see somebody who was so vibrant and strong and so direct shift into this other part of themselves. But my particular perspective is, one, I really always say it's so important just to meet them where they're at. Don't have an expectation of them needing to be who they were or who you want them to be.‚Äù

Willis, 69, was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia in early 2023 after retiring from acting due to aphasia the year before. His family has been open about his ongoing health challenges and their commitment to ensuring he receives the best possible care.

In September, Emma Heming Willis revealed that her husband now lives in a separate residence where he can receive round-the-clock professional support in a calm, secure setting. ‚ÄúIt's what's best for him and for our family,‚Äù she shared at the time.

Through it all, both Demi Moore and Heming Willis have remained steadfast in celebrating Bruce's legacy, his strength, and the deep love that continues to surround him. Their united front has served as a powerful reminder of family, compassion, and enduring devotion.

Title: ‚ÄòGeneral Hospital' Star Asks for Prayers Amid Double Surgery
Description:
‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù star Carolyn Hennesy is asking for prayers as she recovers from one surgery and undergoes another.

The actress, who plays Diane Miller on the hit ABC soap, broke her leg in October and required surgery. At the time, she had to cancel a performance originally scheduled this month.

‚ÄúHello all, due to unforeseen circumstances, like a broken leg, my performance at Vibrato on November 5 has been postponed,‚Äù Hennesy wrote on X. ‚ÄúWe'll get ‚Äòer done, just not on the 5th.‚Äù

She made a similar announcement on Instagram, promising fans that she'll share more details of her injury soon.

‚ÄúHello everyone, sadly (very!) we have to postpone the show on Nov 5th due to a personal injury. More details soon!‚Äù the veteran actress captioned the post.

On November 4, Hennesy took to her Instagram Stories to confirm that her first surgery went well, per Soap Opera Digest. The ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù star also told fans she's having another operation shortly after that.

‚ÄúFirst surgery went well and the second surgery is scheduled for Thursday,‚Äù Hennesy wrote. ‚ÄúAll thoughts and prayers are welcome.‚Äù

Hennesy debuted as Diane Miller on ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù in 2007. Her portrayal of the character earned her two Daytime Emmy Award nominations in the Supporting Actress category.

The last time Hennesy appeared as Diane on ‚ÄúGH‚Äù was on the October 14 episode, where she warned Michael and Carly that they weren't off the hook for framing Willow in Drew's shooting.

Meanwhile, fans were quick to send positive vibes and prayers Hennesy's way. One fan wrote, ‚ÄúPlease get better quickly! The world needs your song and smile!‚Äù

Another commented, ‚ÄúSending positive and healing vibes!! Pray you feel better soon!!‚Äù

Someone chimed in, ‚ÄúMany wishes for a speedy recovery. Next time someone tells you to break a leg, don't take it so seriously!‚Äù

A fan added, ‚ÄúHope your leg surgery went well. Sending prayers your way for a speedy recovery. Miss u on ‚ÄòGH'.‚Äù

Another shared, ‚ÄúI heard about your accident, so very sorry for you. You are one of my favorite GH actresses and I will be sending lots of love & prayers your way for quick healing!‚Äù

Despite her accident, Hennesy has remained upbeat and even joked with fans online. When asked how she broke her leg, the actress encouraged her followers to guess, writing on X, ‚ÄúUse your imagination! Top three get shoutouts!‚Äù

So far, Hennesy hasn't revealed exactly how the accident happened.

Watch ‚ÄúGeneral Hospital‚Äù weekdays on ABC.



Sending you love and hugs and prayers. You are a warrior goddess and bring happiness and joy to your fans! Thanks for being you!

Many blessings for your speedy recovery from surgery! Keeping you in our prayers and sending love and hugs to you!!!

Title: Hallmark Channel Star Astounds Colleagues by Continuing to Work Amid Intense Cancer Treatment
Description:
Beloved Hallmark Channel actress and director Yan-Kay Crystal Lowe has stunned her colleagues by insisting on working through her intense cancer treatments. On November 3, 2025, fellow Hallmark fan-favorite Ashley Williams posted a video of Lowe, 44, hard at work while receiving her latest chemotherapy infusion for stage three breast cancer, a shocking diagnosis she announced in October.

In the video, taken by friend and fellow Hallmark actress Sharon Taylor, Lowe could be seen in her infusion center ‚Äî bald from chemo, bundled up, and hooked up to an IV. Sitting on a hospital table in front of her was a small screen, allowing her to remotely monitor the set of the latest movie she's directing. 

Lowe, who's been part of Hallmark's ‚ÄúSigned, Sealed, Delivered‚Äù cast since the franchise began in 2013, has also been busily building her portfolio as a director over the last couple of years. 

Receiving mentorship, guidance, and opportunities through Hallmark's Make Her Mark program (Williams' brainchild to champion aspiring female directors), Lowe has directed Hallmark movies including 2024's ‚ÄúShifting Gears‚Äù and ‚ÄúThis Time Each Year,‚Äù and 2025's ‚ÄúPie to Die For: A Hannah Swensen Mystery.‚Äù  

Sharing Taylor's video on social media, Williams wrote, ‚ÄúCrystal Lowe was the first woman to go through the women's directing program I founded with Hallmark channel, Make Her Mark. Since then she has directed four more movies with crew and cast raving about her powerhouse skill and clear vision.‚Äù

Williams continued, ‚ÄúCrystal had just booked yet another directing job a few months ago when she was diagnosed with Stage 3 breast cancer. But nothing stops this girl. She fully prepped the movie and then had them set up a live feed so she could direct remotely during chemo.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis video was yesterday,‚Äù Williams added. ‚ÄúNo other text needed here except: Look at our girl go. üöÄ‚Äù

Taylor,  sarcastically quipped, ‚ÄúSo, no big deal. She's just directing a movie while she's getting chemo!‚Äù 

‚ÄúThat's me,‚Äù Lowe smiled, wearing earbuds to hear the dialogue on-set. ‚ÄúDirecting at the same time. Never stops.‚Äù

Many of Lowe's Hallmark colleagues marveled in the comment section about Lowe's impressive commitment and resilience, including her chemo companion Taylor, who wrote, ‚ÄúSo proud of you @officialcrystallowe ! You have the warrior spirit. Love you so much. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù

‚ÄúGrand Ole Opry Christmas‚Äù star Kristoffer Polaha wrote, ‚ÄúThis may be a first in world history. üî•üî•üî•‚Äù and Williams replied, ‚Äúleave it to Crystal.‚Äù

Hallmark Christmas queen Lacey Chabert commented, ‚ÄúAmazing üíú all my love to you, Crystal!‚Äù

Williams' famous sister, Kimberly Williams-Paisley, chimed in, ‚ÄúThis is amazing ‚ù§Ô∏èüí™üèª‚Äù

‚ÄúMerry Christmas, Ted Cooper‚Äù star Robert Buckley called Lowe's feat ‚ÄúIncredible ‚ù§Ô∏èüôè‚Äù and ‚ÄúHannah Swensen Mysteries‚Äù star Victor Webster commented, ‚ÄúAmazing!! Get it @officialcrystallowe‚Äù

‚ÄúAn Angel Christmas Match‚Äù star Meghan Ory, whose husband battled tonsil cancer in 2024, wrote, ‚ÄúThis is the best ever!! Love you‚Äù

Hallmark Channel fans also flooded Williams' post with awestruck comments, calling her ‚Äúa force‚Äù to be reckoned with. But some concerned fans also urged Lowe to rest well while she's fighting cancer.  

One wrote, ‚ÄúGreat but also she should take the time she needs to take care of herself. You're also a strong person if you set boundaries and prioritize your well being‚Äù

Williams jumped in to reply, ‚ÄúWe've talked about this. And to be clear, she's doing that too. She says having something to focus on has been instrumental for her during this process. ‚ù§Ô∏è‚Äù

Lowe, who shares a nine-year-old daughter and three-year-old son with her husband, Mike Tomasevich, shared her diagnosis via social media on October 10, telling her followers that to beat her type of breast cancer, her oncology team advised several months of chemo infusions, followed by a double mastectomy, radiation, and reconstruction surgeries.



I have always loved your acting. I am praying for a full recovery for you!!! I am asking for many of my friends to pray earnestly for your healing. Love you !

Crystal,
With your great attitude you have this. You are really doing great. Yes, there will be good days and bad days but in the near future there will be really good days all the time. This is getting you there.
Lots of good thoughts and prayers being sent your way!

Title: ‚ÄòKill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair' Trailer: Quentin Tarantino's Greatest Film Will Finally Go Wide in Its Ideal Form
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Three months ago, we lamented the fact that Quentin Tarantino‚Äòs best film ‚Äî the 258-minute Cannes cut of ‚ÄúKill Bill‚Äù known as ‚ÄúKill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair‚Äù ‚Äî was impossible to see unless you happened to be one of the lucky people living in or visiting Los Angeles on the sporadic occasions when Tarantino would screen his personal print. But our prayers have been answered: On December 5, ‚ÄúKill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair‚Äù will get a nationwide theatrical release!

The release from Lionsgate will include 70mm and 35mm presentations in some markets, allowing fans to see ‚ÄúThe Whole Bloody Affair‚Äù in celluloid purist Tarantino's ideal form. And this ‚ÄúKill Bill‚Äù will be bloodier and more maximalist than even the Cannes cut, since Tarantino is adding a never-before-seen anime sequence that brings the running time up to 271 minutes.

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòDie My Love' Review: Jennifer Lawrence Goes Full Feral in Lynne Ramsay's Intense, Exhausting Postpartum Psychosexual Frenzy The ‚ÄòPredator' Franchise Is Hollywood's Blankest Canvas 

The ‚ÄúWhole Bloody Affair‚Äù version of ‚ÄúKill Bill‚Äù is a clinic in how a few editorial changes can completely alter the emotional impact of a film. [Warning: spoilers ahead.] The complete version doesn't just slap the two ‚Äúvolumes‚Äù of ‚ÄúKill Bill‚Äù as they were originally released together; Tarantino also makes minor changes that shift the dramatic emphasis in profound ways. 

 










The most significant alteration is the removal of the final moment of ‚ÄúKill Bill: Volume 1,‚Äù in which Bill (David Carradine) reveals that the Bride's (Uma Thurman) daughter is still alive. By taking just this line out of the movie, Tarantino delays the revelation so that we learn of the Bride's daughter's fate at the same moment she does ‚Äî creating a moment of immense power around four hours into the movie that benefits from the cumulative effect of everything that has built up to it.

‚ÄúKill Bill: The Whole Bloody Affair‚Äù will also be presented unrated, which means all the gore of the Cannes cut will be restored to its full color glory. Seen in this form, ‚ÄúKill Bill‚Äù is the ultimate ‚Äúmore is more‚Äù movie, a film stacked from beginning to end with every pleasure and every emotion that the cinema has to offer ‚Äî it's violent, funny, sweet, nasty, poignant, contemplative, frenetic, pulpy, and philosophical, and as we wrote back in August, if it's not the best movie anybody ever made it's certainly the most movie anybody ever made. 

It's hard to think of a better early Christmas present for cinephiles than this long-awaited release. Check out the trailer below.

Title: ‚ÄòPluribus' Review: Vince Gilligan's Intrepid Sci-Fi Series Is Greater Than the Sum of Its Parts
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

This review can't tell you what happens in ‚ÄúPluribus.‚Äù Not the twists, of course, but not the basic premise either. Apple's embargo list is so extensive, it makes answering prospective viewers' most common question ‚Äî ‚ÄúSo, what's that show about?‚Äù ‚Äî all but impossible.

While far from a rarity these days ‚Äî many screeners sent to critics come with episode-by-episode spoiler lists, or NDAs that require us to watch a Spider-Man cartoon ‚Äúout of sight or hearing of anyone else‚Äù ‚Äî the intensifying control exhibited by distributors is ultimately one more method of keeping everyone on message. If writers can't describe the show in their own words, they'll have to use the words provided by press notes, trailers, and other public-relations materials. The less that can be said, the more likely the same things will be said, taking us from commercialism to conformity all before the actual reviews are ground down to feed a Rotten Tomatoes score (which is, I'm told, what people really value).

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòDie My Love' Review: Jennifer Lawrence Goes Full Feral in Lynne Ramsay's Intense, Exhausting Postpartum Psychosexual Frenzy ‚ÄòSentimental Value' Review: Joachim Trier's Wise and Ecstatically Moving Family Portrait Searches for Intimacy Through Filmmaking 

The restrictions attached to ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù are only striking then, because they're the one facet of the show that's incongruous with its themes: themes that celebrate individuality and reject compliance; themes that contend what makes us different is what makes us human, and what makes us human is what makes life worth living; themes about the effort required to do what's right, while acknowledging that being right isn't all that matters.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






So while I can't tell you what happens in ‚ÄúPluribus,‚Äù I can tell you (I think) that ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù is desperate to be heard. Every aspect of Vince Gilligan's massively weird and weirdly massive science-fiction series is tailored to pinpoint the essence of humanity and highlight what makes it so vital, flaws and all. Yes, that also means many perceived flaws could just as easily be viewed as attributes, which makes for quite the mind-fuck when trying to acknowledge what's frustrating about a show that's easy to admire, impossible to pin down, and worthy of loving, even if getting there feels a little strange.

The first seven episodes of ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù remind me quite a bit of the first seasons of Gilligan's last two series, ‚ÄúBreaking Bad‚Äù and ‚ÄúBetter Call Saul.‚Äù (Maybe you've heard of them?) Before the former became a modern classic, its debut was considered a touch plodding and a tad dark. It had the right materials but didn't really start cooking until Season 2. ‚ÄúBetter Call Saul,‚Äù as the prequel to TV royalty, was given more leeway from first reactions. Sure, skepticism over Saul Goodman (Bob Odenkirk) as a leading man was soon dispelled, but what made me dubious about joining Jimmy for his lonely ride to Omaha, Nebraska was how damn bleak it looked. Saul wasn't too silly to carry the drama, his arc was just too damn sad.

 










See how that turned out? As a great man once said, the bones are the money, and the bones of ‚ÄúBreaking Bad‚Äù and ‚ÄúBetter Call Saul‚Äù were as sound as they come, allowing Gilligan & Co. to flesh out the rest of their thrilling character studies into some of the best dramas the small screen has ever seen.

I obviously can't say ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù is destined for similar standing. The bar is too high, the timing is too soon, and all ideas (even from the same great mind) are not of equal promise. The first season has its fair share of flaws, mainly when it comes to momentum. Rather than drive viewers to keep watching, cliffhanger endings can accidentally foreground inaction in the preceding hour. Similarly, Gilligan's devotion to process ‚Äî observing the dedicated methodology required to accomplish a mundane task, whether it's forging documents or making phone calls ‚Äî gets away from him sometimes and throws off the pacing, which is already unsteady thanks to the general shapelessness of our protagonist's overall journey. 

A protagonist you say? Yes, ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù is led by Carol Sturva (Rhea Seehorn), the first and foremost example of the series' many good bones. A thriving romantasy author who hates her own books and a cynical introvert who still knows how to work a crowd, Carol's life is changed forever in the click of a cigarette lighter. Everything she was working toward is gone, along with everyone she once knew ‚Äî although ‚Äúgone,‚Äù when it comes to her select friends and chosen family, is certainly up for debate. 

 










What's not is that Carol, in a key departure for the man who invented Walter White, is a hero. If the vague description above sounds like any one of the world-altering moments society has faced in the last decade or so, then you're already attuned to what ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù is talking about. She is our pandemic avatar, our post-election surrogate, our survivor of the AI apocalypse, and she is none of those people ‚Äî not exactly. Gilligan's fresh premise allows Carol to remain on viewers' emotional wavelength while embarking on an adventure detached from single, simple real-world parallels. And Seehorn, an unquestionable star throughout ‚ÄúBetter Call Saul,‚Äù pushes herself to searingly soulful extremes, time and time again, in a performance demanding as much as Tom Hanks in ‚ÄúCast Away‚Äù or Will Forte in ‚ÄúThe Last Man on Earth.‚Äù

Honestly, I thought more of the latter than the former throughout Season 1. The premiere builds to an extended parody of sorts, both haunting and hysterical at once, and its black yet bubbly sense of humor only spreads from there. It often winks without winking, letting a joke sit just beneath the surface, waiting to be picked up, and it treats its dramatic layers with similar nonchalance. Marshall Adams' camerawork is steady and stunning, Denise Pizzini's production design is colorful and clarifying, and Jennifer L. Bryan's costumes are cozy and clever. In other words, ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù rewards acute attention and an engaged mind, which would be more than enough reason to recommend it even if it wasn't also a sharply observed celebration of the human condition.  

 










‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù is at its best when it doesn't have to over-explain itself. The how's and why's of Carol's unprecedented situation are given ample consideration, but parts of the world-building can still feel like an afterthought. Combined with a very loose plot, perhaps it's easier to explain what ‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù isn't rather than what it is. It's not dressed like classic science-fiction, but it regularly uses science to explain its fiction, often to deliriously imaginative ends. It's not your typical doom-and-gloom post-apocalyptic drama, but it is a show set after a version of the apocalypse and filled with layers of existential dread. It's not a fast-paced thriller, but it is thrilling and moves at its own calculated pace. It's not an antihero show, but its hero is flawed, unpredictable, and distinct. 

In a few weeks, it will be easier to talk about ‚ÄúPluribus.‚Äù Until then, I humbly recommend paying attention to how it makes you feel. The strangeness is the point, and the strangeness is worth savoring. 

‚ÄúPluribus‚Äù premieres Friday, November 7 on Apple TV with two episodes. New episodes will be released weekly through the finale (Episode 9) on December 26.

Title: Netflix and Calm's ‚ÄòTrain Dreams' Partnership: Marketing While You Sleep
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

Points for creativity: Netflix partnered with mental wellness app Calm to create an immersive audio experience inspired by its Oscar-aspiring ‚ÄúTrain Dreams.‚Äù The collaboration, launching today, represents Netflix's first venture on the Calm platform and a potential blueprint for how specialty films can cut through the noise by targeting audiences when they're asleep.

The 20-minute ‚ÄúSleep Story x Soundscape‚Äù hybrid transforms Clint Bentley's drama into a meditative audio journey, featuring narrator Will Patton alongside the film's original score and sound design. Adapted from Denis Johnson's Pulitzer-nominated novella about a railroad laborer in the early 20th century American West, ‚ÄúTrain Dreams‚Äù explores themes of solitude, loss, and resilience ‚Äî the kind of contemplative territory where Calm's 100 million users already spend their time.

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòIn Your Dreams' Review: Kid Siblings Try to Sleep Off Their Parents' Relationship Problems in a Forgettably Generic Adventure from Netflix Animation How ‚ÄòIn Your Dreams' Pushes CG Animation Style to Differentiate Fantasy and Reality 

The Calm team worked with the film's sound designer, Lee Salevan, and composer Bryce Dessner, utilizing the film's sound stems and score cues overlaid with sections of dialogue from Bentley and Greg Kwedar's script. 

 










The odds are stacked against independent and specialty films capturing audience attention. However, this may represent a new kind of counterprogramming: Rather than shout louder, this collaboration markets while you sleep. 

Calm previously collaborated with superhero franchises like ‚ÄúVenom: The Last Dance‚Äù (voiced by Tom Hardy as Eddie Brock and Venom), but this is the first film partnership to create one of its Sleep Stories.

Calm has also previously created Sleep Stories from public-domain classics like ‚ÄúPride and Prejudice‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe Wizard of Oz,‚Äù and enlisted talent like Walton Goggins and Lin-Manuel Miranda to narrate original Sleep Stories like ‚ÄúThe Yard Sale‚Äù and ‚ÄúAdventures in Puerto Rico.‚Äù

The film stars Joel Edgerton, Felicity Jones, and William H. Macy, with Patton's narration carrying over to the Calm experience. The distribution strategy extends beyond Calm's app, with Netflix sharing the soundscape across YouTube, Instagram, and X.

Title: The ‚ÄòPredator' Franchise Is Hollywood's Blankest Canvas
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

It's not easy to be a legacy Hollywood franchise in 2025. Decades of box office dominance for any character recognizable enough to hold up a ‚Äúcinematic universe‚Äù moniker inevitably fell through, and the pandemic-fueled streaming wars yielded an era of oversaturation that rendered even cultural touchstones like Spider-Man and ‚ÄúStar Wars‚Äù feeling a little trite. The bar to interest us in something we've seen before is higher than ever. So why on Earth is the ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù franchise having a moment?

Ten years ago, nobody would have ever labeled the ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù series ‚Äî which launched with John McTiernan's 1987 Arnold Schwarzenegger vehicle before spawning three decades of mediocre sequels that occasionally intermingled with the ‚ÄúAlien‚Äù franchise without any larger central planning ‚Äî a blue chip I.P. Its struggles began with the depressingly Schwarzenegger-free ‚ÄúPredator 2‚Äù that hit theaters in 1990, and it never quite found an identity until 2022's ‚ÄúPrey,‚Äù despite myriad reboots and sequel attempts in the meantime.

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòDie My Love' Review: Jennifer Lawrence Goes Full Feral in Lynne Ramsay's Intense, Exhausting Postpartum Psychosexual Frenzy ‚ÄòSentimental Value' Review: Joachim Trier's Wise and Ecstatically Moving Family Portrait Searches for Intimacy Through Filmmaking 

It's something of a miracle that the franchise managed to hang around the zeitgeist for as long as it did. There were no major returning actors or ongoing storylines, save for the Yautja's somewhat inexplicable obsession with intergalactic trophy hunting, and most attempts to reboot the property failed to explain why this series should exist in the first place. The first film‚Äòs brilliance lay in the overdose of human testosterone it provided in the form of Arnold Schwarzenegger and Carl Weathers high-fiving and spitting out iconic quotes like ‚ÄúIf it bleeds, we can kill it.‚Äù You could have inserted almost any monster into the antagonist role and produced a similarly watchable result. Even the film's title made that clear. The film wasn't called ‚ÄúYautja,‚Äù because nobody really cared about the monsters at its core. We just wanted to see tough guys slaying some kind of predator.

 











			Popular on IndieWire		






The franchise lacks the the Campbell-esque mythology of ‚ÄúStar Wars,‚Äù the mainstream appeal of Marvel, the environmental consciousness of ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù‚Ä¶ the list could go on. Its entire value proposition seems to rely on the fact that it was first to market with a catchy name and that it boasts a semi-recognizable creature to trot out in new scenarios every few years.

All of which, to be clear, is complimentary. 

‚ÄúPredator‚Äù might not have had much of an identity for most of my lifetime, but it sure has one now. It can be distilled down to the mantra: ‚ÄúLet Dan Trachtenberg cook.‚Äù His 2022 film ‚ÄúPrey,‚Äù which took the ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù movies back in time to 1719, starred Amber Midthunder as a young Comanche woman who has to take down a Yautja with an arsenal of weapons that's far more rudimentary than the machine guns that Arnold had to work with. The direct-to-Hulu movie was fresh, fun, and the last thing anyone was expecting from the series. And its appeal was instantly communicable to anyone with even a passing interest in blockbusters, regardless of their familiarity with ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù lore. Really, who wouldn't want to see a battle between bows and arrows and a hyper-advanced alien species with a penchant for trophy hunting?

The success of ‚ÄúPrey‚Äù landed Trachtenberg the job of de facto ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù showrunner, and his stewardship of the franchise has followed the ‚ÄúWhat else do you want to see these crazy alien guys do?‚Äù ethos to splendid results. He followed that with the excellent animated anthology ‚ÄúPredator: Killer of Killers‚Äù (co-directed with Joshua Wassung) that saw the Yautja face off against a viking, a ninja, and a World War II fighter pilot for no apparent reason other than the desire to see if one really tough thing could kill another really tough thing. There was no narrative justification for any of it, and yet it's impossible to deny that it was all cool as hell!

 










Just when it seemed like Trachtenberg and company might have had a repeatable formula figured out, they swerved in another direction with ‚ÄúPredator: Badlands.‚Äù The new film, which opens in theaters this weekend, flips the script by casting a Yautja as the protagonist for a change. It follows Dek (Dimitrius Schuster-Koloamatangi), a runt of the litter who is cast out of his tribe by a father who despises his weakness. He's sent to the deadly planet Genna, where every flora and fauna has evolved to be as lethal as possible, and given the seemingly impossible task of killing a fierce creature known as the Kalisk. Rather than an imposing bad guy to slay before he slays you, this Yautja is now presented as a vulnerable hero who has to learn to show empathy and team up with others. What a concept!

It doesn't set up any obvious direction for the ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù movies to go next, which is precisely why I'm so curious to watch the next one. At a cultural moment when we've watched all of our favorite franchises do what they do best so many times that nothing feels sacred anymore, maybe our best reprieve from the monotony is a franchise that never quite figured out what it does best. The next ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù adventure could believably be anything from a legacy sequel with Arnold Schwarzenegger to a period romance in which a Yautja tries to court a wife in 19th century England, and we've been conditioned to just take it all in stride. 

 










Which creative has the best job in Hollywood? Taking out obvious unicorns like Christopher Nolan who can reliably lean on their name and resume to make anything they want, the answer would have to be someone who can maintain an affiliation with an I.P without having any real creative limitations imposed on them. My default answer to that question used to be Charlie Brooker ‚Äî ‚ÄúBlack Mirror‚Äù is technically an I.P., but the show's anthology format essentially means he has a budget and a built-in audience for any original sci-fi idea under two hours. But I now think the case could be made that Trachtenberg has the best gig within the studio system, as he could cram a career's worth of original blockbuster ideas into the loosely-defined boundaries of the ‚ÄúPredator‚Äù franchise. Given that he's three-for-three so far, I doubt I'm alone in hoping he does just that.

There's a lesson to be learned within all of this for any filmmaker with big ideas who isn't quite breathing the rarified air of A-list directors with blank checks. Instead of pursuing chances to pitch reboots of Hollywood's most beloved properties, scraping the bottom of the barrel might afford you more opportunities to make films that truly feel your own. Franchise fatigue is real, but Dan Trachtenberg has convincingly made the case that the solution lies in starting with underdeveloped franchises. 

 










A 20th Century Studios release, ‚ÄúPredator: Badlands‚Äù opens in theaters on Friday, November 7.

Title: ‚ÄòFire and Water: The Making of the Avatar Films' Review: Disney+ Docuseries Reminds Us That Good Movies Will Always Be Made by Real People
Description:
By providing your information, you agree to our Terms of Use and our Privacy Policy.
				We use vendors that may also process your information to help provide our services. This site is protected by reCAPTCHA Enterprise and the Google Privacy Policy and Terms of Service apply.

In what now feels like a humbling admission of my own naivet√©, I sat down to watch ‚ÄúFire and Water: Making the Avatar Films‚Äù under the baseless impression that Disney+'s new streaming documentary was a legitimate creative exercise in its own right, and therefore worthy of review. My bad. 

I knew, of course, that its release was timed to stoke interest in next month's ‚ÄúAvatar: Fire and Ash‚Äù (my interest in which requires no further stoking, I assure you), just as I knew better than to expect the most corporate of movie studios to serve up a candid, ‚ÄúMegadoc‚Äù-like glimpse behind the scenes of a James Cameron set just a few short weeks before the headstrong auteur's latest blockbuster is set to open in every multiplex on planet earth. 

 








Related Stories ‚ÄòDie My Love' Review: Jennifer Lawrence Goes Full Feral in Lynne Ramsay's Intense, Exhausting Postpartum Psychosexual Frenzy The ‚ÄòPredator' Franchise Is Hollywood's Blankest Canvas 

And yet, if only because the ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù franchise is so deserving of more serious examination, it never occurred to me that a feature-length window into the intricacies of its creation would settle for being a transparent piece of sponsored content. Or that, even worse, it would be arbitrarily divided into episodes in order to inflate the view count and/or pander to short attention spans (Eywa wept). 

 










Directed by Thomas C. Grane, ‚ÄúFire and Water: Making the Avatar Films‚Äù is so unabashedly a glorified EPK that it opens with Cameron imploring viewers to stick around till the end for a sneak peak at the next installment of the franchise (spoiler alert: While the eventual clip promises to be a crucial scene in the actual movie, it's a bit whatever out of context). Back when America was a real country and physical media was still a multi-billion dollar industry, this kind of thing would be automatically packaged on every Blu-ray from ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù to ‚ÄúZack and Miri Make a Porno.‚Äù 

In fact, some ‚Äî or even most? ‚Äî of the footage in ‚ÄúMaking the Avatar Films‚Äù was included on the collector's edition disc that Disney released for ‚ÄúThe Way of Water‚Äù two years ago. I'd be all for offering subscribers ‚Äúfree‚Äù access to that content, but for a service that provides so little original programming, it feels somewhat disingenuous to frame this as a major event. 

And yet, for all of those complaints, it's undeniably fascinating to watch how Cameron and his team put these marvels together, and there is at least some value to seeing a more fully collated look at how the very blue sausage gets made. That value stems from the other thing that Cameron announces directly to camera at the start of the doc: ‚ÄúI want to let you in on a little secret,‚Äù he says. ‚Äú‚ÄòAvatar' films are not made by computers. They're made by people.‚Äù 

 










True enough, while the documentary that follows has a heavy emphasis on the bespoke technology behind the franchise's living alien world (specifically as it pertains to the subaquatic challenges invited by ‚ÄúThe Way of Water‚Äù), every instance of on-set problem-solving ‚Äî every detail of how that technology was leveraged towards creating a singularly immersive sense of wonder ‚Äî is visibly grounded in the work of brilliant artists and engineers. Clear as that already was to anyone who's sifted through the various featurettes that have been made about these films, the 75-minute running time of Grane's whatever this is allows him to hammer the point home with greater emphasis than ever before. 

While Cameron has been a bit more bullish about incorporating AI into his workflow than you might expect from the man who invented Skynet (to say nothing of the hideous AI upscaling he recently inflicted upon several of his greatest films), ‚ÄúMaking the Avatar Films‚Äù is nothing if not a testament to the fact that the most sophisticated motion pictures ever created are indivisibly human at heart. 

Indeed, ‚ÄúMaking the Avatar Films‚Äù is nothing but a testament to that fact, but it's totally enjoyable to watch so far as such testaments go. The project has the hodgepodge structure of a dozen Blu-ray bonus features cut together, but it adheres to the general chronology of Cameron and co. figuring out how to shoot performance capture underwater. While the director is a militant visionary who refuses to take ‚Äúno‚Äù for an answer, there's something enjoyably childlike to his process of trial-and-error. 

 










We don't get to see him ideating about the characters or the story beats (this entire documentary takes place on one of two soundstages, save for a brief excursion to the Bahamas in the middle), so our entire sense of his creative drive is focused on figuring out how to make the movie's aquatic stunts feel believable to the naked eye. As a result, that challenge reads as less of an obstacle than an excuse ‚Äî a manufactured invitation to do things that had never been done before. As Cameron puts it, a mischievous smile on his face: ‚ÄúThe second you decide to make a movie underwater, you've just opened a gigantic can of whoop-ass on yourself.‚Äù

We watch as Cameron and his team come to the realization that dry-for-wet wire work isn't convincing enough to get the job done, which gives them permission to ‚Äúthink of it like the space program‚Äù and model the ‚ÄúWay of Water‚Äù soundstage after NASA's training facilities, complete with massive water tanks. But every solution brings another five problems along with it, as the crew soon realizes that the infrared lighting scheme they used on the first ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù won't work in an environment that's 800 times denser than air. Oh no, I guess they'll just have to shoot with infrared and ultraviolet light at the same time and invent a program that allows them to synthesize the two camera feeds in real-time. 

 










Subsequent headaches inspire a similar creative giddiness, to a degree that left me wondering if Cameron was as fulfilled by writing the movie's script as he was by figuring out that he could address a crucial lighting issue by coating the surface of the water tank in tiny white ping-pong balls. The wave machine someone invented to simulate the oceans of Pandora risks crushing the actors to death under eight pounds of steel? I guess the boys will just have to put their heads together and design an elaborate, jail-like structure to keep people safe from the device. Shooting ‚Äúwet for wet‚Äù requires the cast to hold their breath for several minutes at a time? That sounds like a great excuse to hang out with underwater parkour expert Kirk Krack for several weeks on end ‚Äî freediving lessons for everyone! It's basically just billionaire summer camp for nerds.

Having said that, the most compelling aspect of this doc isn't the tech itself, but rather how these newfangled tools allow Cameron to reinforce the most basic aspects of cinematic storytelling. For all of the toys at his disposal, Cameron never loses sight of ‚Äî and is always driven by ‚Äî the simple fact that Pandora will never feel real to audiences if it doesn't feel real to his actors. ‚ÄúActing is truth in imagined circumstances,‚Äù Sam Worthington pops up to remind us, but the ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù movies wouldn't be able to engineer a fraction of their emotionality if not for how far Cameron went to make its circumstances easier for his cast to imagine. 

 










We don't get to see much in the way of the director helping Sigourney Weaver or Zoe Salda√±a to better understand their motivation or whatnot, but perhaps that's because he didn't really have to do that. The freediving, the man-made waves, the specific PSI that Neytiri would require to pull open a half-submerged door on a sinking ship, and the rest of the solved problems that Cameron assigned himself allow the swimming pool to function as a portal to another world, as primordial emotion and newfangled technology are braided together as organically as Na'vi dreadlocks into the roots of the Hometree in order to make both sides of the equation seem as real as the back of your hand. 

To a less rewarding but even more lucid degree than the ‚ÄúAvatar‚Äù movies themselves, this slapdash making-of documentary serves as an all too necessary reminder that digital film technology ‚Äî including but not limited to AI ‚Äî is little more than a parlor trick, if not for the presence of a human soul behind it. 

‚ÄúFire and Water: Making the Avatar Films‚Äù is now available to stream on Disney+.

Want to stay up to date on IndieWire's film reviews and critical thoughts? Subscribe here to our newly launched newsletter, In Review by David Ehrlich, in which our Chief Film Critic and Head Reviews Editor rounds up the best new reviews and streaming picks along with some exclusive musings ‚Äî all only available to subscribers.

Title: Rosal√≠a: LUX Album Review
Description:
8.6

 Best New Music 

Genre:

Pop/R&B

Label:

Columbia

Reviewed:

November 7, 2025

Rosal√≠a is redrawing pop's map at a stunning pace. Her first two records, Los √Ångeles and El Mal Querer, brought flamenco into the mainstream; the second fractured the genre from its tradition, unearthing a pop architect intent on stitching sacred text with street expression. Then came MOTOMAMI, a world born of Caribbean heat and unbridled nerve, cementing her as an experimental auteur burning through sounds like a master technician. But when the earthly map felt complete, she spoke directly from the heavens: LUX.

The Spanish superstar's fourth album is a heartfelt offering of avant-garde classical pop that roars through genre, romance, and religion. Arranged in four movements and sung in 13 languages, its orchestral pop storms down from the skies and leaves, in its thundering aftermath, a field guide for pop's seekers, those who believe the answers to love, desire, and creative purpose might yet be contained in three or four minutes at a time. It's not a dopamine machine like MOTOMAMI, but it rewards listeners who ache for more from pop artists: more feeling, more risk.

For all its scholarship and borderless histories, LUX isn't a massive homework assignment; it's an operatic lament for a new generation, an exquisite oratorio for the messy heart. Yes, the credits read like a conservatory (the London Symphony Orchestra; Catalan choirs; MOTOMAMI collaborators Noah Goldstein and Dylan Wiggins; Pharrell; and arrangements from Caroline Shaw and Ang√©lica Negr√≥n, to name a few), but Rosal√≠a's voice remains at its center. With her as its lodestar, LUX advances like a crusade to conquer the mysteries of human existence. On opener ‚ÄúSexo, Violencia, y Llantas,‚Äù she announces her plan: ‚ÄúHow nice it'd be, to come from this Earth, go to Heaven, and come back to the Earth.‚Äù She spends the next hour detailing this process from start to finish through flamenco pop revelations (‚ÄúLa Rumba Del Perdon‚Äù), waltzing insults (‚ÄúLa Perla‚Äù), existential operatic swells (‚ÄúMemoria‚Äù), and songs that feel entirely new and genreless (like ‚ÄúFocu'Ranni or ‚ÄúNovia Robot‚Äù).

LUX takes desire as a holy problem and divinity as a complex solution. Love, men, God, femininity, death, surrender‚Äîthey all swirl around this idea, expressed in Japanese, Ukrainian, Chinese, Italian, and nine more languages. How did Rosal√≠a begin to understand life's thorniest questions? She read hagiographies of female saints and poets like Teresa de Jesus, Sun Bu'er, and Hildegard Von Bingen; she studied feminist theory while preparing lines for her acting debut in Euphoria. She looked to these devout women for inspiration and synthesized their messages into her own creed as a 33-year-old pop star trying to make sense of all this insanity.

In this way, LUX feels like a modern scripture of feminine celebrity. ‚ÄúMy God I'll obey‚Ä¶ I'll burn the Rolls‚ÄëRoyce‚Ä¶ tirar√© mis Jimmy Choos,‚Äù she vows on ‚ÄúSauvignon Blanc,‚Äù promising to renounce luxury in exchange for some ascetic peace. On ‚ÄúReliquia,‚Äù she shrugs off fame as a form of sacrifice‚Äî‚ÄúMy heart's never been my own‚Äù‚Äîand offers herself as a relic for the world to hold. On the vinyl and CD-exclusive track ‚ÄúDios es un stalker,‚Äù Rosalia becomes a flawed God, her obsessions with other humans become feral‚Äì‚ÄúI'm your shadow,‚Äù ‚ÄúI'm the labyrinth‚Äù‚Äìshe delivers over clean bass and choral filigree like a fucked up prayer, proof that not even otherworldly heroes are free from mortal flaw.

It's no secret that Rosal√≠a's engagement to Puerto Rican superstar Rauw Alejandro ended in 2023, right before she began work on this record. LUX also details the journey of heartbreak and recovery first through a pious lens, then blows it up tenfold. On the standout ‚ÄúLa Perla,‚Äù she cuts men without flinching‚Äî‚Äúemotional terrorist,‚Äù ‚Äúred flag andante‚Äù‚Äîa controlled evisceration that could sit next to Fiona Apple in the museum of magnificent dismissals. On the other side is ‚ÄúMio Cristo,‚Äù where she deifies a lover's pain‚Äî‚ÄúMy Christ cries diamonds‚Äù‚Äîonly to face the hard question: ‚ÄúHow many blows should have been hugs?‚Äù ‚ÄúNovia Robot‚Äù takes a broader approach with a mock infomercial for a compliant, purchasable girlfriend. It's a satire that plays like one of the album's clearest theses: a woman's beauty owes no debt to male consumption.

On LUX, forgiveness is a religious doctrine, captured best by Flamenco pop highlight ‚ÄúLa Rumba del Perd√≥n.‚Äù Modern flamenco stars Estrella Morente and Silvia P√©rez Cruz sing through family betrayals and street parables while Rosal√≠a argues that forgiveness is an active decision that restores control to the wounded, even ‚Äúwhen power beats out love,‚Äù or your best friend steals that ‚Äúuncut kilo in the drawer.‚Äù The closing movement is smaller in frame but larger in feeling. ‚ÄúMem√≥ria‚Äù takes inventory of what remains, and ‚ÄúMagnolia‚Äù releases what will not: ‚Äúlife flashed me its knife, took everything I had, and I thanked her for that.‚Äù The promise from the opener holds: She returns to earth, not a saint, but simply finished, landing on that rare pop sensation of being held, seen, and leveled all at once.

Can all this easily be labeled pop music? Yes, but not the kind that chases the algorithm. LUX sits comfortably beside albums that use concert music as a conduit to turn heartbreak into archetypal feminine quests: Vulnicura, Ys, Hounds of Love, Titanic Rising, MAGDALENE. The ‚Äúbangers‚Äù are there; you're just more likely to find them in a pasture than on a billboard. ‚ÄúFocu'Ranni‚Äù swells over chopped voice samples in a melody that feels like the older, wiser cousin to El Mal Querer's ‚ÄúPienso en tu mir√°‚Äù; ‚ÄúPorcelana‚Äù raps, gleams, and snarls through descriptions of a tortured diva; and ‚ÄúDe Madrug√°‚Äù speeds by like a meteor aimed at an ex-lover. LUX enlarges the capacity of Rosal√≠a's artistry without abandoning the direct address that made people fall for her in the first place.

Rosal√≠a has pulled this rebellious trick before‚Äîtabula rasa, new world, start again‚Äîbut LUX feels like the first time she's built the whole stage and lets the camera linger. It becomes a place where pop and religion‚Äîeach with its own set of testimonies, beliefs, and icons‚Äîcan converge on the grounds of deeper understanding: ‚ÄúWhen God descends I ascend/And we'll meet halfway,‚Äù she sings on ‚ÄúMagnolia.‚Äù If you come expecting ‚ÄúCon Altura,‚Äù you're likely to be lost at first. Stay. Let the pieces unfurl, and enjoy what's been revealed. You don't need a personal investment in Rosal√≠a to get shivers down your spine when she begs you to throw flowers over her casket.

Title: Black Eyes: Hostile Design Album Review
Description:
7.7

Genre:

Rock

Label:

Dischord

Reviewed:

November 7, 2025

About two minutes into ‚ÄúBurn,‚Äù the second track on Black Eyes' Hostile Design, Daniel Martin-McCormick yelps ‚ÄúKill your shitty parents/let their blood flow free‚Äù: a signal that, in the two decades since the band last released new music, it has lost none of its anger. Born at the start of the century in the D.C. punk scene, Black Eyes‚Äîwith two drummers, two bassists, two singers, and a guitar that sounded like Rowland S. Howard possessed by the ghost of Sonny Sharrock‚Äî upended the genre's norms, melding no-wave noise and funk, percussive assault, and obtuse but guttural screeds against Bush-era America. By the time their second album, Cough, came out, a free-jazz influence had taken center stage, with songs that sounded like the work of a band ripping themselves to pieces only to reassemble them in new, misshapen ways. That the band's last show happened before Cough even came out is unsurprising; a hurricane only holds together for so long.

So when Black Eyes reunited in 2023, it felt like a minor miracle. Hostile Design, in turn, is faced with an imposing question: How do you capture chaos in a bottle twice, years removed from the initial energy that fueled it? Though they've spent the past two years playing their older material on tour, Hostile Design doesn't sound like an attempt to retread old ground; instead, in typical Black Eyes fashion, they attempt something new. Synthesizing the explosive tension and jazz squawk of their previous work while bringing their love of dub to the forefront, the band seems gleeful to stretch their songs into new forms and shapes; half of the album's tracks are over six minutes long, luxuriating in echo and delay.

‚ÄúUnder the Waves‚Äù rides maybe the grooviest basslines the band has ever made, its flow not even disturbed by a noisy saxophone solo. Album closer ‚ÄúTomTom‚Äù is cavernous, the band triggering  every reverberation that their instruments can muster, crafting a hypnotic sprawl haunted by Hugh McElroy's constant chatting in Haitian Creole. Not that the band has lost all their energy. They build opener ‚ÄúBreak a Leg‚Äù instrument by instrument, thumping bass piling atop frantic drums piling atop broken sax notes until it all explodes in the song's final minute, Martin-McCormick and his guitar both letting out distorted screams, ripping his vocal chords to ribbons just like he did over 20 years ago.

What hasn't shifted at all in the intervening years is the band's anguish about and rage towards the politics of the moment. ‚ÄúPestilence‚Äù is not only a call aganist genocide, but also an attack on the apathy of people who allow it to continue. ‚ÄúBurn‚Äù's call to kill your parents is not for random shock value, but represents earnest anger towards the way older generations have discarded the futures of adolescents. The band sings in four different languages, emphasizing the global nature of the issues they confront. Black Eyes' lyrics have always been more stream-of-consciousness impressions than didactic rants, and it can occasionally be tricky parsing out which current horror has struck their ire. Yet among the bedlam, some sentiments are unmistakable: shrieks about ‚Äúthe spilled blood of slaughtered children‚Äù or how ‚Äúthat girl just has a mission to make it down the hallway at night‚Äù make the band's moral stances crystal clear.

Fans hoping Hostile Design would be a repeat of the same manic, bursting-apart intensity that defined Black Eyes' earlier work will probably leave disappointed, though it's hard to imagine any dedicated listener expecting Black Eyes to do the same thing twice. In the reunion world, punk albums feel risky: Can a band come within a mile of the energy, fury, and madness they crafted in their youth? And even if they can, does the result expose how paint-by-numbers the structures of the genre can be? But Black Eyes have once again shown how little they care about those structures, and decades later, it's heartening to witness them recommit to exploring whatever unknown avenues their music takes them down, rather than just indulging nostalgia. Hostile Design, like its title implies, may hold little comfort, but it does offer catharsis: a reminder to not only look long at these modern horrors, but howl back at them.

Title: Keiji Haino / Shuta Hasunuma: U TA Album Review
Description:
6.7

Genre:

Experimental

Label:

windandwindows / Temporal Drift

Reviewed:

November 7, 2025

Keiji Haino detests the frivolous. As a teenager in the late '60s, the songs he heard about love and peace seemed facile, like they didn't contain a genuine message. ‚ÄúWhat I wanted to do and how I wanted to do it was totally different from The Beatles and their ilk,‚Äù he said in 1997. Central to his self-described outsider status was something beyond adolescent edginess: a craving for something new. Years later, he explained that his artistic endeavors and lifestyle are one and the same: ‚ÄúI want to live each and every moment at its best and to the fullest. And I think that to regret is to repeat.‚Äù It can be odd to hear about such mutability, as the Japanese avant-rock and free-improv maestro has a vast back catalogue that can be consistently described as volcanic, punishing, and relentlessly brutish. But U TA, his new LP with composer Shuta Hasunuma, is a true anomaly: Haino only contributes vocals, and the music is resolutely soothing.

U TA was recorded in a studio after Haino and Hasunuma performed an iteration of it live in 2021. The goal, however, wasn't to recreate what they'd previously done. Haino arrived with only lyrics in hand and, without knowledge of what Hasunuma would play, reacted in real time to the latter's bevy of soft instrumentation. U TA opens with ‚ÄúSky,‚Äù a gorgeous track defined by graceful piano melodies and atmospheric synthesizers. Haino begins by whistling, the sound like a comforting breeze, and then offers poetry: ‚ÄúBroken pieces of me/becoming dust of light/Falling upon/the earth below.‚Äù There are so many details that stand out: the way a word reverberates in the ether, but remains perceptible when listening closely; the sudden wavering of his voice, occasionally breaking the speaking/singing boundary; the intimacy of hearing him clearing his throat. Haino's voice has often sounded mystic or violent, largely because he approaches singing as an extension of the surrounding music. Hasunuma forces him into a different realm, one that's gentle and genteel.

Throughout his decades-long career, Haino has created profoundly beautiful albums that tap into primal emotions. The key is in isolating the listener: His music can sound apocalyptically desolate, or like being thrown into a whirlwinding cyclone, or like you're staring at an empty sky while taking a long drag of a cigarette. This album feels very different: It's inviting and personal. Especially stirring is ‚ÄúNumber,‚Äù where Haino patiently sings, stretching each phrase across an expanse of glossy, electronic sputters. Its endearing simplicity and naivety recalls Ryuichi Sakamoto's collaborations with Alva Noto, or Nuno Canavarro's Plux Quba. If there's an overarching feeling achieved across U TA, it's that of warm vulnerability.

The following two tracks magnify each member's role: ‚ÄúPause‚Äù is a ruminative ambient piece ornamented with birdsong, while ‚ÄúDrops of overflowing smiles are falling‚Äù is a sound poetry exercise recalling Henri Chopin and Niikuni Seiichi. On the latter track, Haino repeatedly utters variations of the titular phrase, his voice layered until it congeals into pure texture. Interestingly, Haino largely avoids extended vocal techniques (something that characterized his a capella album Un autre chemin vers l'Ultime) throughout U TA, ensuring that these pieces stay in the realm of songs instead of formal exercises. It's why the LP is most successful when the two musicians keep things light and remain in total lockstep, like on the Harold Budd-esque ‚ÄúPeople,‚Äù where Haino even says, ‚ÄúI want to bring our powers together.‚Äù Beautifully, his breath and Hasunuma's crystalline piano chords periodically fade out in dreamy fashion.

Hasunuma hasn't released an album like U TA either. While he's collaborated with numerous artists‚Äîfrom Foodman to Jeff Parker to Arto Lindsay‚Äîhis music is usually cartoonish and cute, if not insufferably saccharine. Haino's presence adds a necessary prickliness. ‚ÄúLatency,‚Äù for example, would be trite and aimless without any vocals. Hasunuma matches his energy on ‚ÄúFinger,‚Äù creating a cavernous space for Haino's voice to echo quick, pained bursts. ‚ÄúGush‚Äù is a more unwieldy affair, with Haino warbling amidst white noise, metallic clangs, handclaps, and other percussive accoutrements. The most shocking moment on the album arrives partway through ‚ÄúRest,‚Äù when pinging synths dot the track and feel entirely out of place amidst soft harpsichord-like melodies. In that moment, Haino is unfazed and continues singing, grounding the entire piece. It recalls what he once said about his music: ‚ÄúI sing because I want a sense of becoming one with someone outside of myself.‚Äù For Haino, music is the great connector, a chance to take part in something authentic.

Title: Mohinder Kaur Bhamra: Punjabi Disco Album Review
Description:
8.4

 Best New Reissue

Genre:

Electronic

Label:

Naya Beat

Reviewed:

November 7, 2025

The scene that played out on a quiet evening in Southall in 1982 would be familiar to any South Asian immigrant home: a family gathered around the dining table, loose sheets of paper scattered across its surface, a mother lovingly exhorting her son to eat proper food. Nothing in that image announces that history is being made. But in the Bhamra household, the kitchen was also a songwriting laboratory, where Mohinder Kaur Bhamra and her sons were quietly cooking up a radical new sound, one that reflected the hybridity of their √©migr√© existence.

Armed with the SH-1000‚Äîthe first Roland synthesizer‚Äîand a Compurhythm CR-8000 drum machine, 22-year-old Kuljit Bhamra would spend all day crafting siren-horn loops and bubbling basslines, melding disco and funk experiments with the rhythms and melodies of Punjabi folk. His 11-year-old brother, Ambi, would often sit in on the drum machine. In the evening, they'd play the demos for Mohinder, who'd pen Punjabi lyrics to sing over them, delivering songs of love and yearning in a melismatic, full-throated voice. Those sketches would crystallize into Punjabi Disco, the first-ever British Asian electronic dance album‚Äîa joyous, loose-limbed romp through Punjabi-tinged disco, funk, psychedelia, and proto-acid house.

The family kitchen is an odd birthplace for a pioneering dance music record, but in the context of the 1980s British Asian experience, it's also a fitting one. The dancefloors that would usually be the crucible for new sounds hadn't materialized yet‚Äîracism and the conservatism of the community's elders kept young South Asians out of London's nightclubs, and the daytimer bhangra-and-bass raves of the late '80s were still a few years away. Outside the home, the only places where music was regularly performed were gurdwaras and temples‚Äîwhere the songs were strictly devotional‚Äîor during community weddings.

Those were the arenas where Mohinder‚Äîtrained as a gyani, or Sikh devotional singer‚Äîhoned her voice after moving to the UK in 1961. As the first woman in her community to sing at the local gurdwara, she was already a quiet trailblazer, moving between kirtan, Sikh wedding ceremonies, and secular repertoire: Punjabi folk songs, ghazals, Hindi film music. Kuljit, her eldest son, accompanied her on tabla from age 6; his brothers Satpaul and Ambi later joined on the mandolin and accordion.

But the weddings they played were sedate affairs, men and women seated apart, movement limited to tapping feet. The Bhamras set out to change that‚ÄîKuljit and his brothers clearing tables to open space on the floor, Mohinder urging the women forward, sometimes refusing to sing unless they were allowed to dance too. This represented one of the first desegregated South Asian dance spaces in Britain, and on Punjabi Disco, the Bhamras created a new sound to fill it, drawing inspiration from the disco mania that followed 1979's Saturday Night Fever.

Recorded over a few days at a local studio owned by Savage Process bassist Rik Kenton, Punjabi Disco was a family project through and through‚ÄîMohinder on vocals, Kuljit and Ambi handling the synthesizer and drum machine, Kuljit's high school friend Trevor Michael Georges on bass, and brother Satpaul designing the neon-sign cover. ‚ÄúEverything just clicked,‚Äù Kuljit says. ‚ÄúWe thought people would love it.‚Äù

Instead, the release was sabotaged: the label copied the concept, issued a cheap imitation, pressed only a few hundred copies of the original, and distributed them so badly that Kuljit ended up hand-delivering stock to local shops. The record disappeared, and life moved on‚ÄîMohinder kept singing folk sets at community events while Kuljit became a foundational figure in UK bhangra. Punjabi Disco lingered only as rumor, lost to all but obsessive crate-diggers.

Now the record is getting a new lease on life, thanks to a 2xLP reissue by L.A. label Naya Beat. The album's nine tracks have been completely remixed and remastered, with a tenth, previously unreleased song added. Heard today, the record still sounds fresh‚Äîbright, rough-edged, and alive with discovery. Though disco is obviously a major reference point, Kuljit's compositions don't try to recreate the genre wholesale. Instead, he absorbs disco conventions and then reshapes them into something much more idiosyncratic.

On opener ‚ÄúDisco Wich Aa,‚Äù samba rhythms and laser toms lead into keening synth riffs, time-worn folk melodies grafted wholesale onto a machine-built sound world. Over the skittering backbeats and sped-up disco groove of ‚ÄúNainan Da Pyar De Gaya,‚Äù snake-charmer synth leads trade space with Mohinder singing about love at first sight in full-bodied head voice. The jaunty ‚ÄúPyar Mainu Kar‚Äù exists somewhere between classic Bollywood disco and proto-D'n'B, layering synthesized folk phrasing over a percolating bassline and frenetic percussion.

Other songs drop disco's four-to-the-floor rhythms and foray into more left-field territory, offering tantalizing glimpses of an alternative future where funk‚Äîrather than hip-hop or reggae‚Äîformed the substrate for British Asian music experimentation. ‚ÄúPar Toon Ki Janay‚Äù is a funk fusion masterclass, complete with duelling synth-and-guitar solos over a skeletal, shaker-led funk groove. Mohinder's voice vamps up and down the track, playfully chiding a clueless amour (‚ÄúI've let you into my heart, but what do you know?‚Äù). ‚ÄúMainu Apne Pyaar Wich‚Äù is the album's standout track, opening with a classic disco-funk riff before slipping into a low-slung, liquid groove that borders on the hypnagogic. Georges' bassline ripples its way through the track, buoyant and elastic, guided by a repeated chromatic synth note that keeps plucking it into forward motion. It sounds like funk music that got all fucked up on lean.

Not all 10 tracks are as cohesive and accomplished. There are moments, such as on ‚ÄúAye Deewane,‚Äù where the production could afford to cut back a little, offering more space to Mohinder's vocals. Occasionally, Kuljit's ambitions seem to outpace the technical capabilities of the musicians, or even the early synthesisers themselves. But these flaws also give the record a certain DIY charm, reminding us that this remarkable collection of songs began life as a family experiment, conceived around dining tables and in community wedding halls.

In what has become a Naya Beat trademark, the Punjabi Disco reissue comes with six new remixes, as well as a cover of ‚ÄúNainan Da Pyar De Gaya‚Äù by label owners Turbotito and Ragz, featuring vocals by Priya Malik of Say She She. These reinterpretations update the sounds of Punjabi Disco for contemporary dancefloors, to varying degrees of success; Mystic Jungle's reggae spin on ‚ÄúMainu Apne Pyaar Wich‚Äù is a highlight, as is Baalti's disco-meets-UK-club-music remix of ‚ÄúDisco Wich Aa.‚Äù But the real testament to the record's power is that the originals still work‚Äîyou could drop them into a set tonight. The Bhamras knew instinctively that great dance music isn't about gear or genre purity; it's about collapsing the distance between people. ‚ÄúCome to the disco,‚Äù Mohinder sings on the opener, ‚Äúdon't be distant.‚Äù Four decades on, the invitation still lands.

Title: Who's the ‚ÄòEmotional Terrorist' Rosal√≠a Sings About on ‚ÄòLa Perla'?
Description:
By 

	Tom√°s Mier



	The soft guitar strums that open ‚ÄúLa Perla‚Äù offer a contrast to the unapologetic lyrics that open the Lux standout. ‚ÄúHello, peace stealer,‚Äù Rosal√≠a sings, almost coyly, pointing to her target from the first line.


	The string orchestra builds as Rosal√≠a sings to a former lover ‚Äî ‚Äúa playboy,‚Äù ‚Äúa narcissist,‚Äù ‚Äúan enchanter‚Äù ‚Äî who ‚Äúspends money he has and doesn't have,‚Äù and takes first place on the ‚Äúpodium of disillusion,‚Äù who's earned a ‚Äúmonument to dishonesty.‚Äù


	‚ÄúThe local disappointment, a national heartbreaker/An emotional terrorist, the biggest disaster in the world,‚Äù she sings. ‚ÄúHe's a pearl, no one trusts him/He's a pearl, one to be very careful with.‚Äù


	But who is the song about?


	There seem to be two real possibilities for who ‚ÄúLa Perla‚Äù might be about ‚Äî but most fans think it's Rauw Alejandro, the Puerto Rican heartthrob and reggaeton star, whom Rosal√≠a dated from 2021 through 2023. Together, they released a collaborative project titled RR inspired by their love, and Rosal√≠a even got a tattoo of his first name under her left breast. (She references the tattoo on ‚ÄúFocu ‚ÄòRanni,‚Äù another Lux track, singing, ‚ÄúI have your name on my ribs, but your initials were never on my heart.‚Äù) 

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	The breakup was chronicled all over the media and tabloids, and full of public displays and musical antics. Shortly after the breakup, Alejandro released a song titled ‚ÄúHayami Hana‚Äù on which he insisted that infidelity was never the reason for their split, and poured out compliments for Rosal√≠a. And then there was the 2023 Latin Grammys a few months later, where he took the stage ‚Äî in Rosal√≠a's home country of Spain, no less ‚Äî to perform a cover of Laura Pausini's heartbreak song ‚ÄúSe Fue,‚Äù which compares the end of a relationship to a powerful storm that ruined him. ‚ÄúHer fairytale smile is gone / The sweet honey I tasted on her lips is gone,‚Äù he sang.

	











	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Kendrick Lamar, Bad Bunny, Lady Gaga Lead 2026 Grammy Nominees		
	









	
	
		
					Journey Announce Final Frontier North American Farewell Tour		
	









	
	
		
					A Robotaxi Killed a Beloved Bodega Cat in San Francisco. People Are Pissed		
	









	
	
		
					Mar√≠a Zardoya and Role Model Met Onstage. Now They're Bonding Over Breaking Out in 2025		
	









	But back to Rosal√≠a's ‚ÄúLa Perla:: ‚ÄúAfter a powerful verse from Yahritza y Su Esencia‚Äòs Yahritza about this mystery man's need for a psychiatrist, Rosal√≠a joins with a sing-songy, spoken line where she describes how her narcissistic ex would see being called an icon as a ‚Äúreductionist narrative.‚Äù She then sings, ‚ÄúLoyalty and faithfulness/Are a language he'll never understand/His masterpiece, his collection of bras.‚Äù Aside from Rauw Alejandro's bra-catching skills at concerts, the reggaetonero even has a song with Daddy Yankee titled ‚ÄúPanties y Brasieres‚Äù on his album Saturno.





	
		Editor's picks
	
	











	
	
		
					The 250 Greatest Albums of the 21st Century So Far		
	














	
	
		
					The 100 Best TV Episodes of All Time		
	









	Rauw may be the obvious answer, but if you ask any Rosal√≠a love-life connoisseur, the other possible subject of the song could be The Bear actor Jeremy Allen White. The two of them sparked dating rumors after being spotted together in the year following her breakup with Alejandro. White wore a rose brooch at the Critics' Choice Awards in January 2024, which many fans took as a nod to the singer. However, they seemed to split later in the year as Allen retreated from public view to play Bruce Springsteen in the biopic Deliver Me From Nowhere. We have no information about White's bra collection, though.

Title: Blake Lively Claims $161 Million in Damages From Alleged 'It Ends With Us' Smear Campaign
Description:
By 

	Nancy Dillon



Blake Lively claims the alleged ‚Äúretaliation campaign‚Äù waged against her during the 2024 release of the Justin Baldoni-directed movie It Ends With Us caused her more than $161 million in damages.


	The estimate was buried in a disclosure document obtained by Rolling Stone and made public Wednesday in Lively's ongoing sexual harassment and retaliation lawsuit against Baldoni, It Ends With Us producer Jamey Heath, Wayfarer Studios partner Steve Sarowitz, and the men's publicists.


	In the document dated July 25 and attached as an exhibit, Lively's lawyers claim the so-called smear campaign triggered $56.2 million in lost income linked to past and future acting and producing gigs, as well as speaking engagements and appearances. That number includes an estimated $18.3 million in lost wages for August 2024 through the time the trial is expected to start in March, as well as $37.9 million in lost earnings down the line.


	The lawyers claimed Lively's beauty brand, Blake Brown, also suffered a profit hit of $49 million, while her Betty B Holdings beverage company suffered estimated lost earnings of $22 million. In addition, the lawyers alleged ‚Äú65,000,000 impressions of the defamatory statements‚Äù cost Lively another $34 million in ‚Äúreputational harm.‚Äù

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	In her lawsuit filed last New Year's Eve in New York, Lively claimed Baldoni, her co-star on the film, and the other defendants subjected her to ‚Äúdisturbing‚Äù sexual harassment during production and then targeted her with a ‚Äúsophisticated, coordinated, and well-financed‚Äù smear campaign after she spoke up on set. Lively claims they wanted to ‚Äúsilence‚Äù and ‚Äúeviscerate‚Äù her before she had a chance to possibly go public with her claims.

	











	In her original lawsuit, Lively's lawyers said her damages exceeded $75,000, but they offered no further estimates. The July disclosure, first reported by Variety, offers a new window into how much she's actually seeking, which is subject to expert testimony provided at trial. The lawyers added in the filing that Lively also plans to seek ‚Äúpunitive damages in an amount not less than three times the amount of Ms. Lively's actual damages.‚Äù


	Attempts to reach lawyers on both sides were not immediately successful Thursday.





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Kendrick Lamar, Bad Bunny, Lady Gaga Lead 2026 Grammy Nominees		
	









	
	
		
					Journey Announce Final Frontier North American Farewell Tour		
	









	
	
		
					A Robotaxi Killed a Beloved Bodega Cat in San Francisco. People Are Pissed		
	









	
	
		
					Mar√≠a Zardoya and Role Model Met Onstage. Now They're Bonding Over Breaking Out in 2025		
	









	Baldoni responded to the retaliation lawsuit with a $400 million defamation lawsuit filed against Lively and her husband, the actor Ryan Reynolds, in January. A federal judge provisionally dismissed the defamation case last June and then entered a final judgment formally dismissing the case last week after Baldoni elected not to file an amended complaint.


	‚ÄúNo deadlines were missed. Our clients chose not to amend their complaint to preserve appeal rights. In the meantime, we are focusing on Ms. Lively's claims,‚Äù Bryan Freedman, a lawyer representing Baldoni and Wayfarer, said in a Tuesday statement. ‚ÄúWe remain fully committed to pursuing the truth through every legal and factual avenue available and look forward to our day in court.‚Äù

Title: Millie Bobby Brown, David Harbour Downplay Bullying Rumors With 'Stranger Things' Premiere Reunion
Description:
By 

	Daniel Kreps



Millie Bobby Brown and David Harbour shut down rumors of bullying and harassment on the Stranger Things set by posing together and praising each other at the final season premiere event on Thursday.


	‚ÄúI've obviously had a really special bond with David because we have a father-daughter relationship, and we do every scene together,‚Äù Brown told Entertainment Tonight on the red carpet. ‚ÄúYou really get to see that in Season Five.‚Äù


	Harbour told ET of Brown, ‚ÄúI adore her, and I've been proud to watch all of them grow up and become great artists. I doubt it will be the last time we'll see each other in this world or work together.‚Äù


	The red-carpet reunion between the two actors comes just a week after the Daily Mail reported that Brown allegedly filed harassment and bullying claims against Harbour ‚Äî who plays her adoptive dad of sorts on the series ‚Äî with producers of the hit Netflix show prior to shooting the final season. 


	‚ÄúThere were pages and pages of accusations. The investigation went on for months,‚Äù a source told the Daily Mail. Brown's specific accusations against Harbour were not revealed, but no sexual impropriety was reportedly alleged.

	










			Popular on Rolling Stone		







	While the co-stars didn't address the bullying report on the red carpet, Stranger Things creators Ross and Matt Duffer and director Shawn Levy were each asked about its veracity. 


	‚ÄúObviously, you understand I can't get into personal on-set matters, but I will say we've been doing this for 10 years with this cast, and at this point they're family and we deeply care about them,‚Äù Ross Duffer told the Hollywood Reporter. ‚ÄúSo, you know, nothing matters more than just having a set where everyone feels safe and happy.‚Äù

	











	‚ÄúI've read a bunch of stories, and they range from wildly inaccurate to ‚Ä¶ there's so much noise around it. But the truth is that we view this crew and this cast as family, and so we treat each other with respect, and that's always been bedrock,‚Äù Levy added.


	‚ÄúAt the end of the day, that's the job. You have to create a respectful workplace where everyone feels comfortable and safe, and so we did everything to build that environment. And we're proud of the fact that we did so.‚Äù





	
		Trending Stories
	
	






	
	
		
					Kendrick Lamar, Bad Bunny, Lady Gaga Lead 2026 Grammy Nominees		
	









	
	
		
					Journey Announce Final Frontier North American Farewell Tour		
	









	
	
		
					A Robotaxi Killed a Beloved Bodega Cat in San Francisco. People Are Pissed		
	









	
	
		
					Mar√≠a Zardoya and Role Model Met Onstage. Now They're Bonding Over Breaking Out in 2025		
	









	Brown has recently shown she has no issue firing back at those who bully her, pushing back against the scrutiny and criticism she has faced regarding her appearance.


	‚ÄúI respect journalism. I love reading articles on my favorite people and hearing what they're up to. I understand that there's paparazzi, even though it's invasive, even though it feels like shit to me ‚Äî I know that's your job,‚Äù Brown told British Vogue earlier this month. ‚ÄúBut don't, in your headline, slam me at the get-go. It is so wrong, and it is bullying, especially to young girls who are new to this industry and are already questioning everything about it.‚Äù
