Title: Flight cuts underway due to shutdown as transportation secretary warns impact could get much worse
Description:
Live Updates


‚Ä¢ Flight cuts underway: A 4% reduction in domestic flights at 40 airports in major US cities is in effect following an order from the Federal Aviation Administration. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy warned the percentage could rise to 15-20% if the shutdown doesn't end ‚Äúrelatively soon.‚Äù
    


            ‚Ä¢ Hundred of flights affected: About 800 flights have been canceled today, and travelers are frustrated with the disruptions. On top of the cutbacks, air traffic control facilities are still reporting staffing problems. Impacted by travel woes? Tell us about it here. Track flight cancellations here. 



‚Ä¢ Gridlock in Congress: Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer plans to present a unified Democratic-offer to end the shutdown on the floor of the Senate this afternoon, according to an aide, as Democrats signaled yesterday they were prepared to block GOP plans to force a vote today to reopen the government.
    


            If the federal government shutdown doesn't end ‚Äúrelatively soon,‚Äù  the Department of Transportation may decide increase the number of cancelled flights at designated airports to 15 or 20 percent, Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy told Fox News today, citing the likelihood of air traffic controllers not reporting to work.
    


            ‚ÄúI don't want to see that,‚Äù Duffy said, noting that ‚Äúif controllers start coming to work and the pressure goes down, we can move those numbers in the other direction.
    


            ‚ÄúThis is a moment-by-moment assessment,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúWe're doing all we can to make sure travelers are safe as they move through the airspace.‚Äù
    


            The secretary also decried the damage the shutdown has caused on recruiting candidates for the large number of unfilled air traffic controller roles.
    


            ‚ÄúThis makes it more difficult to get the best and the brightest young people to sign up to be air traffic controllers,‚Äù Duffy said. ‚ÄúAnd, again, after the shutdown is over and everyone stops covering it, I'm going to be the one that's still dealing with trying to get young people in to take these great jobs.‚Äù
    


            Senate Minority Leader Chuck Schumer plans to present a unified Democratic-offer to end the shutdown on the floor of the Senate later this afternoon, according to a Democratic aide briefed on the plans.
    


            Schumer is expected to speak around 2:30 p.m. ET and has asked his fellow Senate Democrats to be on the floor as well.
    


            Democrats are expected to present an offer that includes a one-year extension of the enhanced Affordable Care Act subsidies, a stopgap bill into January ‚Äì along with three full-year funding bills ‚Äì and a demand for some way to rein in Trump's attempts to override Congress's power of the purse, according to three sources familiar with the discussions.
    


            The exact details were still being hammered out as of Friday afternoon and could still change.
    


            There is little expectation that Republicans will take their offer, given fierce GOP resistance to extending the Affordable Care Act subsidies with no reforms. Instead, it's an attempt to showcase Democratic unity and attempt to put more pressure on Republicans heading into the weekend.
    


            Majority Leader John Thune acknowledged Friday he's seeking to reengage Democrats in negotiations to reopen the government and told reporters the chamber was not expected to vote Friday on a compromise deal they had been working towards.
    


            He said the Senate would instead take up legislation it had previously attempted to pass, a measure from GOP Sen. Ron Johnson that would pay federal workers who are required to work through the government shutdown. Senate Democrats are widely expected to block the measure, according to two people involved in caucus discussions.
    


            Thune said that talks between centrist Democrats and Republicans have abruptly fallen off after a burst of optimism among GOP leaders earlier in the week.
    


            ‚ÄúI thought we were on a track,‚Äù Thune said. ‚ÄúAnd then yesterday, everything kind of ‚Äì the wheels came off, so to speak. So, it's up to them. I mean, like I said, we're ready to engage when they are.‚Äù
    


            Democrats insist Republicans have not given them what they want, which is a deal to extend the expiring Affordable Care Act subsidies as part of any funding measure.
    


            Thune earlier said Friday he hoped the Senate could vote on the compromise deal in the coming days. The deal that centrist Democrats and Republicans were working towards was a short-term measure to fund the government for several weeks, paired with a package of three full-year appropriations bills covering key agencies. Negotiations were also underway to attach some kind of measure promising a future vote on the expiring health care subsidies.
    


            As the federal government shutdown impacts travel across the United States, we're bringing you a snapshot of what the lawmakers are doing in Washington, DC, and what's happening at US airports.
    


Here's what to know: 



Congress: Senate Majority Leader John Thune indicated he expects the Senate to be in session this weekend if Democrats block a plan today to reopen the government.
    


White House: President Donald Trump, who is meeting today with Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orban, will be attending the Washington Commanders NFL game on Sunday against the Detroit Lions, according to a White House official. He isn't scheduled to meet with lawmakers on the shutdown.
    


At airports: There have been at least 15 reports of staffing problems at the Federal Aviation Administration air traffic control facilities that have prompted delays across the country, even as airlines cut 4% of their flights at 40 major airports.
    


Economic impacts: The shutdown's impact on the economy is ‚Äúfar worse‚Äù than expected ‚Äúbecause it's gone on for so long,‚Äù National Economic Council Director Kevin Hassett told Fox Business Friday, predicting a downturn in GDP if the shutdown continues. The record-breaking shutdown, which has reached day 38, has left Americans feeling worse about the economic outlook, according to the latest University of Michigan consumer sentiment survey.
    


CNN's Ellis Kim, Kit Maher and Aaron Cooper contributed reporting to this post. 



            As the federal government shutdown drags on and Senate Democrats are expected to oppose a vote to reopen the government again today as they seek more commitments on dealing with rising health care costs, open enrollment for 2026 coverage on the Affordable Care Act exchanges is underway.
    


            Millions of consumers are now seeing just how expensive their health insurance policies will be without the enhanced premium subsidies that have been in place since 2021.
    


            If Congress does not agree to renew enhanced subsidies, those who will be hit the hardest by soaring premiums include lower-income, older and middle class enrollees.
    


            Enrollment has more than doubled since 2021, when the enhanced premium tax credits were introduced. Should the enhanced subsidies lapse, about 4 million more people are expected to be uninsured in 2034, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
    


            Read more and view additional graphics on this topic here.
    


            When Luana Griffin's mother was diagnosed with terminal cancer this past week, she booked a flight to go spend a few days with her.
    


            Now, the Federal Aviation Administration's slowing of air traffic is putting that trip in jeopardy, at a time when she and her family are already under an immense amount of stress.
    


            Griffin's trip, from San Diego to Sacramento, is planned for next week, she told CNN. Griffin said she has limited windows of time to be able to see her mom because she is working a contract job.
    


            Any delay or cancellation of her return flight could cause her to miss work the next day, she said.
    


                    ‚ÄúI have very limited time left with my mom and so many other decisions, this is the last thing I need,‚Äù she told CNN in an email.
                





            On top of that, Griffin, who usually flies six to eight times a year, said she paid much more for this round trip than she usually pays for similar flights to Sacramento.
    


            ‚ÄúI am the main person providing for my family. The additional cost doesn't help with Christmas around the corner,‚Äù she told CNN in an email.
    


CNN's Marnie Hunter contributed reporting to this post.



            There have been at least 15 reports of staffing problems at the Federal Aviation Administration air traffic control facilities that have prompted delays across the country Friday, even as airlines cut 4% of their flights at 40 major airports.
    


            Here's a look at some of the recent impacts:
    


            ‚Ä¢ The control tower at Washington's Reagan National airport is again short-staffed until 10 p.m. ET tonight after an earlier staffing problem was reported there this morning. The FAA says delays for flights headed to DCA average about 83 minutes and only 24 planes will be allowed to land each hour.
    


            ‚Ä¢ Flights headed to San Francisco today must wait on the ground about an hour for takeoff. The control tower at SFO is short-staffed until 3 p.m. ET.
    


            ‚Ä¢ Atlanta Hartsfield-Jackson International Airport is seeing delays for planes departing of 45 minutes, and increasing, according to the FAA. The Atlanta Air Route Traffic Control Center, which manages flights en route at higher altitudes, is short-staffed this afternoon.
    


            ‚Ä¢ Newark Liberty International Airport's control tower is short-staffed until 2 p.m. ET. The TRACON facility handling flights approaching and departing Newark was short-staffed earlier.
    


            ‚Ä¢ The control at airports in New Orleans, Austin, Texas and Ontario, California, were also short-staffed today.
    


            ‚Ä¢ TRACONs, which handle flights arriving or departing airports, do not have their full complement of controllers this afternoon in Houston, Phoenix, and Southern California.



            ‚Ä¢ And centers, which handle flights en route, are also short-staffed this afternoon in Dallas and Jacksonville. The Boston center was short-staffed earlier today.
    


            The longer the shutdown drags on, the more risks could emerge ‚Äî especially as controllers go longer without pay, a union leader said earlier this week.
    


            But the newly announced flight cuts will help maintain safety, the head of the National Transportation Safety Board said yesterday.
    


                    ‚ÄúTHIS is safety management, the very foundation of our aviation system, and it's the right thing to do,‚Äù National Transportation Safety Board Chair Jennifer Homendy posted on X.
                





            The Federal Aviation Administration's emergency order calls for airlines to reduce operations at the 40 selected airports on a ‚Äúrolling schedule‚Äù through next Friday, November 14, which means travelers will still see disruptions well into next week.
    


            According to the emergency order released Thursday, airline operations ‚Äúshall be reduced seven days in advance on a rolling schedule.‚Äù Airlines needed to provide an ‚Äúinitial list of reduced operations‚Äù to the FAA today for reduced operations from today until next Friday. Tomorrow, airlines must ‚Äúretain a reduction of at least 10%‚Äù for November 15.
    


            That means even if the government were to reopen next week, travelers can still see flight cancellations. Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy reaffirmed that air travel wouldn't immediately return to normal if the government reopened because air traffic controllers probably wouldn't return to work right away.
    


            ‚ÄúIf the government opens, on day one, will I see an immediate response from controllers? No, the union is telling me it's going to take time to get them all back,‚Äù Duffy said this morning at Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport.
    


            Although many airlines are not preemptively calling off flights in advance, some cancelations have been reported through Saturday and Sunday, according to FlightAware.
    


            Like many brides, Alicia Leva has dreamed about her wedding day for months, taking each detail into consideration as she prepares to exchange vows surrounded by the people she loves the most.
    


            But with more than half of her guests attending from across the country amid a reduction in domestic flights at 40 airports in major US cities, Leva sees travel plans unraveling fast.
    


            Now, the day before her wedding in South Florida, the 32-year-old fianc√©e has collected travel itineraries of all her guests and has her eyes glued to FlightAware, she told CNN, noting most of her guests' flights have been delayed, but not canceled so far.
    


            ‚ÄúWhen I found out about the flight delays, I was just incredibly anxious,‚Äù she said. Leva doesn't want her wedding woes to triumph over others who have been deeply affected by the government shutdown, but is still mourning her original vision of the couple's special day.
    


            Mickayla Vialpando joined the wedding travel frustration as she waited in anticipation at Denver International Airport this morning staring at the departure screens tracking her Cancun-bound flight for two wedding celebrations, she told CNN affiliate KCNC.
    


            While Vialpando's flight wasn't affected by any cancellations ‚Äî the flight reduction order ‚Äúdoes not require a reduction in international flights,‚Äù a joint statement from the Federal Aviation Administration and the Department of Transportation said. However, airlines ‚Äúmay use their own discretion to decide which flights are canceled to reach the order's goal.‚Äù
    


            Either way, Vialpando said, ‚Äúit's a lot of added stress.‚Äù
    


            With about 800 flight cancellations today, major carriers are impacted differently across the board. Take a look at how each airline is faring below:
    


            Senate Majority Leader John Thune indicated he expects the Senate to be in session this weekend if Democrats block a plan today to reopen the government.
    


            Asked if senators will work through the weekend if the funding vote fails, Thune told reporters, ‚ÄúI think that should be the expectation.‚Äù
    


            Senate Democrats are expected to oppose a vote to reopen the government, as they seek more commitments on dealing with rising health care costs.
    


            Thune also told reporters the math hasn't changed on eliminating the filibuster, as President Donald Trump has suggested doing.
    


            ‚ÄúIn my view, the issue here is Senate Democrats, so I'm going to keep my fire trained on them. But the practical reality is, it is a function of arithmetic and the math isn't there for‚Äù abolishing the filibuster, he said.
    


            The government shutdown, which started on October 1, has prevented many federal employees from getting paid.
    


            Air traffic controllers and Transportation Security Administration screeners are considered essential employees during the shutdown and are expected to go to work. But they're not getting paid, and some have needed to find other sources of income to pay the bills.
    


                    ‚ÄúControllers are resigning every day now because of the prolonged nature of the shutdown,‚Äù said Nick Daniels, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association. ‚ÄúWe're also 400 controllers short ‚Äî shorter than we were in the 2019 shutdown.‚Äù
                





            Hundreds of flights at 40 major airports across the country have been canceled today, following an order from the Federal Aviation Administration to reduce  flights as the government shutdown drags on.
    


            The cancellations have left some travelers with no backup options. Some have resorted to traveling long distances by car with Hertz reporting a significant uptick in car rentals.
    


            Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy is citing safety concerns as the reason for cutbacks, but acknowledged the exact number of flight reductions is somewhat arbitrary. The administration has said that the number of flight cuts will increase as the shutdown continues.
    


            Here's a look inside airports across the country this morning:
    


            As the government shutdown leaves air traffic controllers working without pay, pilots from North Las Vegas Airport are stepping in to help. This week, a group of pilots delivered food and supplies for controllers, many of whom have small children at home.
    


            ‚ÄúI've been in the situation where I've had an in-flight emergency, and the air traffic controllers make a difference,‚Äù pilot Jeffrey Lustick told CNN affiliate KTNV.  ‚ÄúThey help you get to the ground safely. They alert people that you need help ‚Ä¶ air traffic controllers save lives.‚Äù
    


            Lustick and fellow pilots have made two deliveries so far. He said the pilots' support for controllers is ‚Äúnot political at all.‚Äù
    


            ‚ÄúThe relationship between air traffic controllers and pilots is one of trust ‚Ä¶ they have to be able to survive, and we want them to stay here and continue to provide support to our community,‚Äù he told KTNV.
    


            A reduction in flights across 40 major US airports due to staffing issues caused by the government shutdown is frustrating travelers.
    


Flight disruptions: Delays were reported for flights headed to Newark Liberty International Airport, Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, and Austin-Bergstrom International Airport this morning, as Federal Aviation Administration staffing problems continue to expand across the country.
    


The arbitrary numbers: Sean Duffy, secretary of transportation, said the order to cut US flights ‚Äî up to 10% by next week ‚Äî is due to safety concerns, but acknowledged the exact number is somewhat arbitrary. ‚ÄúIt is not a science, it is (an) art that we're trying to deploy to keep people safe in the airspace,‚Äù Duffy said today. When the government reopens, travel will not bounce back immediately, he said.
    


Cancellations: About 800 flights have been canceled, leaving some travelers with no backup options. Others have resorted to travel by car with Hertz reporting a significant uptick in car rentals.
    


Another apparent dead end day in Congress: As of last night, Senate Democrats signaled they are prepared to block GOP plans to force a vote today to reopen the government ‚Äî until they get more commitments on dealing with rising health care costs.
    


An update on SNAP benefits: The Trump administration made an emergency request to the First Circuit Court of Appeals to pause a federal judge's order requiring the government to fully cover food stamp benefits for tens of millions of Americans in November.
    


            Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy says only an end to the government shutdown can avoid future canceled flights, putting the blame on Democrats.
    


            ‚ÄúIf Democrats are going to go home this weekend, and they've kept the government shut down, that's shameful,‚Äù Duffy told reporters while exiting Reagan National Airport this morning.
    


            Some Democrats, including the ranking member of the House Transportation Committee, have criticized the order to reduce domestic flights ‚Äî which started today at 4% and will rise to 10% next week ‚Äî saying the secretary has not provided enough specifics on the safety need.
    


            ‚ÄúAs many people can't get home, the Senate goes home,‚Äù Duffy told reporters. ‚ÄúThey should be here every day, every weekend, every week trying to find a deal so we can open the government back up.‚Äù
    


            Nick Daniels, president of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association, tells CNN that air traffic controllers will continue to work to ensure the safety of the flying public, but that they can't ‚Äúsomehow suddenly put money in our own pockets‚Äù to support their livelihoods.
    


            ‚ÄúWe're not out here begging for more. We're out here saying, ‚ÄòGive us what we deserve,'‚Äù Daniels said.
    


                    ‚ÄúYes, reducing capacity is one of the main mechanisms to help increase the safety of the system, or Congress could act and open the government today,‚Äù the association's president said, speaking with Kate Bolduan on CNN News Central.
                





            It will take over two months for air traffic controllers to get the proper backpay that they are owed from their October earnings, Daniels said in response to Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy's comment that flights would not go back to normal immediately due to controllers likely all not going back to work right away.
    


            Delays were reported for flights headed to Newark Liberty International Airport, Ronald Reagan Washington National Airport, and Austin-Bergstrom International Airport this morning, as Federal Aviation Administration staffing problems continue to expand across the country, the same day the FAA implemented cuts to airline traffic at 40 major airports.
    


            45-minute delays were reported for Newark-bound flights. The control tower at the New Jersey airport will not have its normal number of workers until 2 p.m. ET, the FAA said in an operations plan. The TRACON facility handling flights approaching and departing Newark is also short-staffed until noon. The airport has seen staffing shortages nearly every day of the shutdown and has reported more than any other facility.
    


            The control tower at Washington's Reagan National airport is short-staffed until 2 p.m. ET and the FAA is currently reporting average delays of about 24 minutes. The control tower at New Orleans International Airport is also short staffed until 2 p.m. ET, but has not yet reported delays. Flights headed to Austin, Texas were also delayed by about 45 minutes, the FAA reported.
    


            Air traffic controllers were also briefly understaffed at Ontario International Airport's control tower in California earlier this morning. The Boston Air Route Traffic Control Center, which handles flights enroute at higher altitudes, is understaffed until 11 a.m. ET.
    


            Since the start of the shutdown, Fridays have historically been one of the worst days for air traffic controller staffing.
    


            ‚ÄúIf you are flying Friday or in the next ten days and need to be there or don't want to be stranded I highly recommend booking a backup ticket on another carrier,‚Äù Frontier Airlines CEO Barry Biffle posted on Instagram.
    


            ‚ÄúDon't book a basic ticket. For example, book Economy on Frontier so you can reuse the ticket value as changes are free or you can get a credit,‚Äù Biffle wrote. ‚ÄúIf your flight is cancelled your chances of being stranded are high so I would simply have a backup ticket on another airline.‚Äù
    


            Delta Air Lines, United Airlines and American Airlines are waiving fees for travelers who want to cancel or change their upcoming flights.
    


            It's also helpful to book directly with an airline instead of through a third-party website. That's because if your flight gets canceled, you might have to deal with another party to resolve the problem.
    


            And try to avoid booking flights with layovers, the US Public Interest Research Group says. The more planes you have to get on to reach your destination, the more chances you have for a flight to be delayed or canceled.
    

¬© 2025 Cable News Network. A Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All Rights Reserved.  CNN Sans ‚Ñ¢ & ¬© 2016 Cable News Network.

Title: Oregon athletes win 'Most Valuable Patriot' award after refusing to share podium with trans competitor
Description:
This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed. ¬©2025 FOX News Network, LLC. All rights reserved. Quotes displayed in real-time or delayed by at least 15 minutes. Market data provided by Factset. Powered and implemented by FactSet Digital Solutions. Legal Statement. Mutual Fund and ETF data provided by Refinitiv Lipper.
      

Track stars and 'Most Valuable Patriot' award winners Alexa Anderson and Reese Eckard join 'Fox & Friends' to address backlash for refusing to share a podium with a biological male and discuss their ongoing fight to protect women's rights in sports.

Two Oregon female athletes were honored at the seventh annual Fox Nation Patriot Awards on Thursday night for their decision to speak out in support of women's rights in sports after refusing to stand on a podium alongside a transgender opponent ‚Äî a decision neither girl realized would become part of the national discourse.

Alexa Anderson, a freshman competing in the pole vault at the University of South Alabama, and Reese Eckard, a member of the Biola University women's track and field team, were awarded the "Most Valuable Patriot Award" at Thursday night's ceremony in Brookville, New York, after they refused to stand on the podium in the Oregon State Activities Association's girls high jump final in May, after a transgender student placed fifth in the event.

Oregon girls' track and field athlete Alexa Anderson. (Courtesy of Alexa Anderson)

In a lawsuit filed after the incident, the girls claimed they were excluded from official photos and that their medals were withheld.

CLICK HERE FOR MORE SPORTS COVERAGE ON FOXNEWS.COM

"I'm so incredibly grateful, and none of this would've been possible without the support of every single one of you who has seen our story, who has shared it and brought our story and our fight into the national spotlight," Anderson said during her acceptance speech.

"I want to start off by thanking God. I thank God that you're all here tonight. I thank God that He gave Alexa and I the courage to stand for truth," Eckard added in hers. "There are so many girls that deserve this award for their courage."

Reese Eckard and Alexa Anderson accept the Most Valuable Patriot Award from Will Cain and Martha MacCallum onstage during the 2025 Fox Nation Patriot Awards at Tilles Center for the Performing Arts in Greenvale, New York, on Nov. 6, 2025. (Roy Rochlin/Getty Images)

The two high school track stars, who have continued in their sport at the collegiate level, joined "Fox & Friends" Friday morning to discuss the award and the impact that decision has had on their lives and the fight for women's rights.

OREGON GIRLS WHO WENT VIRAL FOR REFUSING TO STAND ON PODIUM WITH TRANS ATHLETE FILE LAWSUIT

"To get that award was honestly just such an honor. It was never something that I thought would happen when we stepped off that podium," Anderson said.

She said that, reflecting on the decision to speak out, she "100%" believes it was worth it.

"I think fighting for the rights of women's sports to have a safe and fair environment is going to be a fight we're going to be a part of for years ‚Äì maybe even our lifetime. And it's so incredibly worth it if we can help all these girls to have a safe and fair environment."

Oregon girls' track and field athletes Reese Eckard and Alexa Anderson don't stand on a medal podium next to a trans opponent. (Courtesy of America First Policy Institute)

CLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD THE FOX NEWS APP

Eckard echoed that sentiment.

"It's just crazy to be able to stand up for all the girls who are trying to compete at ‚Äì in just high school or college‚Äì just knowing that we fought so hard to protect women's rights in sports and to be able to say that we took a stand, is just amazing."

Follow Fox News Digital's sports coverage on X, and subscribe to the Fox News Sports Huddle newsletter.

Paulina Dedaj is a Sports Reporter for Fox News Digital.

Title: Tulsi Gabbard's Quest to Bring the ‚ÄòDeep State' Under Her Control
Description:
A memo circulating within the federal government lays out her office's reasoning for wanting to transfer counterintelligence work away from the FBI.

Listen to more stories on the  Noa app.

This article was featured in the One Story to Read Today newsletter. Sign up for it here.

Throughout Donald Trump's first term, his third campaign, and the first 10 months of his second term in office, he and his allies warned darkly of a ‚Äúdeep state‚Äù seeking to thwart his every move. In an address to the National Conservatism Conference in September, Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard said that ‚Äúleaders in the intelligence community‚Äù‚Äîthe massive bureaucracy she runs‚Äîare among the ‚Äútraitors to the Constitution‚Äù who have tried to undermine the president because they oppose his policies.

This kind of public invective is par for the course in the Trump administration. But these attacks have generated real action: Gabbard has revoked security clearances of supposed Trump opponents by the dozen and fired high-ranking staff while the Justice Department busies itself with dismissing civil servants and prosecuting the president's enemies. Now Gabbard's agency, which coordinates among the different elements of the intelligence community, is advocating for legislation that would transfer significant authority over counterintelligence to her office and away from an FBI that her staff has portrayed as the home of a traitorous deep state. The legislation, introduced by House Intelligence Committee Chair Rick Crawford and tucked into a yearly bill authorizing intelligence activities, would establish the Office of the Director of National Intelligence as the lead agency in charge of counterintelligence. The House and Senate must now hash out the shape of the final bill.

Counterintelligence, the work of catching foreign spies, has long been the FBI's bailiwick, and the bureau is vehemently opposed to the transfer. But Gabbard's office seems to believe that the FBI's Counterintelligence Division is irredeemably politicized‚Äîwhich is to say anti-Trump. The contours of this turf war are illustrated in a memo with comments from the National Security Council, the FBI, and Gabbard's office that we have reviewed and that is circulating among government agencies potentially affected by the legislation. ‚ÄúIf we do nothing,‚Äù the memo warns, ‚Äúthe same deep state actors who have egregiously weaponized counterintelligence for political purposes will be empowered.‚Äù The memo was distributed among government agencies last week as part of a process of soliciting feedback on the draft legislation, which the House Intelligence Committee approved a version of in early September.

For now, at least, Gabbard's quest to take control of counterintelligence seems to lack the allies it would need for success. Complicating her bid is the fact that the FBI, the agency she seeks to displace, is itself under the leadership of fellow Trump loyalist Kash Patel‚Äîwho once referred to the agency as ‚Äúone of the most cunning and powerful arms of the Deep State.‚Äù The onetime foes of the deep state now run the place, and their allegiances to conspiracy theories are proving flexible when it comes to protecting their own fiefdoms. Patel's ominous warnings of anti-Trump vipers lurking within the bureau apparently weren't enough to prevent him from allowing the FBI to defend its own turf. Gabbard, in contrast, may have just discovered that ominous warnings of deep-state conspirators aren't enough to persuade the White House to hand her more power.

For months now, Gabbard has accused current and former government personnel who investigated Russia's interference in the 2016 election of taking part in a ‚Äúyears-long coup‚Äù against Trump. FBI counterintelligence played a central role in efforts to stop Russia from meddling in the presidential campaign and to identify the perpetrators.

In Trump's telling, FBI agents are among the core peddlers of the ‚ÄúRussia hoax‚Äù‚Äîthe idea that Democrats and the federal government engineered lies about Russian election interference to falsely tarnish Trump's 2016 campaign. No wonder, then, that Gabbard is proposing to take control over much of the FBI's counterintelligence work. But the White House, thus far at least, seems cool to a major reorganization. ‚ÄúThe administration is opposed to the transfer of counterintelligence responsibilities from the FBI to the ODNI,‚Äù a senior administration official told us.

Gabbard has struggled to find her place in the president's inner circle. Over the summer, her influence had so eroded that one Trump ally called her a ‚Äúnonplayer.‚Äù Trump has also told aides and allies that he's not sure the Office of the Director of National Intelligence is even necessary.

Gabbard has attempted to raise her stock by declassifying documents that she claims allege a grand conspiracy by Trump's enemies to undercut him in 2016. But she is still on shaky footing, and has arguably erred in trying to take on the FBI, a far larger and more bureaucratically powerful organization than the one she runs. Despite Gabbard's impressive-sounding title, the Office of the Director of National Intelligence is a relatively small agency. It dates back only to 2004, when it was established as part of the post-9/11 project of improving cooperation among intelligence agencies, and has never really managed to consolidate its authority over the older and better-established centers of bureaucratic power that make up the nation's intelligence community.

Read: What everyone gets wrong about Tulsi Gabbard

Today, the FBI appears uninterested in giving up any of that power. ‚ÄúThis proposal would significantly duplicate and confuse constrained resources,‚Äù the FBI diplomatically writes in the memo, which includes additional cautionary statements from the National Security Council. The New York Times recently reported on a separate letter to Congress sent in mid-October in which the bureau warned of ‚Äúserious and long-lasting damage to the U.S. national security‚Äù should the intelligence director's office take over counterintelligence authorities.

Asked about these critiques, a spokesperson for the House Intelligence Committee responded that the memo circulated among agencies was ‚Äúout of date‚Äù and that the committee has continued to ‚Äúincorporate remedies to points of concern‚Äù as the bill moves forward. The legislation ‚Äúdoes not move significant parts of the FBI's counterintelligence mission‚Äù to Gabbard's office, the spokesperson said; rather, the bureau's Counterintelligence Division would be ‚Äúbuttressed‚Äù by the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. Gabbard's office sent us a joint statement with the FBI, reading, ‚ÄúThe ODNI and the FBI are united in working with Congress to strengthen our nation's counterintelligence efforts to best protect the safety, security, and freedom of the American people.‚Äù

Counterintelligence can be a tricky area to define. Essentially, it's spy versus spy‚Äîthe work of catching foreign agents and disrupting espionage against the United States. James Jesus Angleton, who led the CIA's effort to identify Soviet moles during the Cold War, famously described the practice as ‚Äúa wilderness of mirrors.‚Äù Now the FBI performs the bulk of counterintelligence investigations. As part of this work, specially trained FBI agents cultivate sources in foreign intelligence agencies. The Office of the Director of National Intelligence, which is largely an administrative agency, has no comparable investigative arm, something law-enforcement officials and intelligence veterans we spoke with were quick to point out.

China is undoubtedly the main focus of FBI counterintelligence operations. In March of this year, an investigation by the FBI and Army counterintelligence led to the arrest of two active-duty U.S. soldiers accused of giving classified information and weapons designs to China. And in July, the Justice Department charged two Chinese nationals with spying on U.S. Navy bases and helping to identify service members whom China's security service might try to recruit.

Crawford's case for the legislation has focused not on fighting the deep state, but on promoting the bill as a means of centralizing the nation's counterintelligence work at the Office of the Director of National Intelligence and cutting through ‚Äúbureaucratic red tape.‚Äù According to the latest public version of the bill, Crawford's proposal would create a new ‚ÄúNational Counterintelligence Center‚Äù under the Director of National Intelligence, which would ‚Äúlead and direct‚Äù the government's spy-hunting work. The head of this new center would have the power to direct different agencies such as the FBI and CIA on how to use their counterintelligence authorities, and require agencies to get sign-off from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence before moving forward with their own plans. The legislation also gives Gabbard's office insight into the FBI's process of investigating leaks or mishandling of classified information.

H. R. McMaster: What Trump got right about national security

Supporters of Crawford's legislation say that the FBI has bogged down counterintelligence work by treating it as a law-enforcement matter. The bureau's job is to gather evidence to bring criminal charges, which is fine as far as that goes, they say. But‚Äîin their argument‚Äîrampant espionage by China, which includes the theft of valuable technical research from U.S. corporations and universities, demands a strategy to disrupt and deter those adversaries, not one that is always premised on bringing cases to court. ‚ÄúThe counterintelligence threat is very real,‚Äù the House Intelligence Committee spokesperson said. ‚ÄúThis is not politics; this is about national security and the safety of Americans in the homeland.‚Äù

Michael Feinberg, a former FBI agent who spent much of his career in the bureau's Counterintelligence Division, questioned this characterization of the FBI's work. (Feinberg was pushed out of the FBI earlier this year as part of the agency's effort to purge agents considered insufficiently loyal to Trump.) ‚ÄúProsecutions represent only one tool used by the organization to thwart foreign spies,‚Äù he said over text. ‚ÄúBoth on its own and with other intelligence community partners, the FBI engages in a wide swathe of activities‚Äîmost never revealed to the public‚Äîto keep our nation's secrets safe.‚Äù

Crawford and Gabbard appear unlikely to get the changes they want, at least in the near term. But with Trump in the Oval Office, sometimes all it takes to turn things around is for a person with a convincing pitch and an enmity for the deep state to sell their idea to the president. In a government stocked with combustible personalities and conspiracy theorists, no proposal, however far-fetched, can truly be declared dead for long.

US stocks extended declines on Friday, putting benchmarks on track to snap a string of weekly gains as investors continued to fret about stretched valuations in the tech sector.

The S&P 500 Index fell 0.5% at 2:29 p.m. in New York, with the benchmark trading below its 50-day moving averageBloomberg Terminal earlier in the session. The tech-heavy Nasdaq 100 Index dropped 1.1%, putting both gauges on track to end a three-week winning streak. Block Inc., Microchip Technology Inc. and Take-Two Interactive Software Inc. were some of the biggest decliners.

Title: Big Tech's AI spending spree: Smart long-term bet or short-term risk?
Description:
In this article

In this Club Check-in, CNBC's Paulina Likos and Zev Fima break down big tech's massive artificial intelligence spending spree ‚Äî debating whether these billion-dollar bets will drive long-term cost savings or weigh on near-term returns.

Mega-cap tech companies are shelling out billions of dollars to build out AI infrastructure. The big question we're asking is whether all this heavy spending will eventually pay off in efficiency or if Wall Street is right to worry about how much they're burning through in the short term.

Concerns about AI-stock valuations seeped into the market this week and slammed stocks.

Many major tech companies ‚Äîincluding the three biggest clouds, Amazon, Microsoft, and Alphabet's Google ‚Äî raised capital expenditure guidance this earnings season, sparking both investor optimism and concern.

Zev Fima, portfolio analyst for the Club, argued the spending is justified: "Too much focus on the short-term is what leads to falling behind in the long term." CNBC reporter Paulina Likos pushed back, noting that "investors haven't seen efficiency gains show up in returns yet."

Watch the video above to see where the debate played out on whether AI investments are real productivity drivers or just expensive promises until proven otherwise.

(See here for a full list of the stocks in Jim Cramer's Charitable Trust, the portfolio used by the CNBC Investing Club.)

Title: Michael Saylor Isn't Backing Down ‚Äî Even as Bitcoin and MSTR Sink
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

Strategy is once again turning to investors to raise capital for expanding its Bitcoin holdings. 

The company has launched a new preferred stock offering that provides investors with steady returns while fueling its ongoing Bitcoin accumulation strategy.

Earlier today, Strategy (formerly MicroStrategy) introduced a new class of preferred shares designed to attract institutional investors seeking fixed returns.

The company raised roughly $715 million through the sale of its 10% Series A Perpetual Stream Preferred Stock (STRE), selling 7.75 million shares at about 92 each and offering investors a 10% annual dividend based on a ‚Ç¨100 share value.

The offering, priced in euros, will help fund additional Bitcoin purchases and cover general corporate purposes‚Äîmost notably, to expand its Bitcoin holdings as prices slide.

The shares offer steady returns, positioning the company as both a Bitcoin proxy and an income investment. By tapping capital markets to boost its reserves, it reasserts its faith in Bitcoin's long-term value.

The paradox is that the company is doubling down just as both Bitcoin's price and its own stock are tumbling.

The move comes as Bitcoin fell below $100,000, and Strategy's shares have dropped more than 27% in the past month, reflecting growing pressure on the company's aggressive Bitcoin strategy.

The market downturn has reignited debates over whether Strategy's approach‚Äîtying its corporate value so closely to Bitcoin's price‚Äîcan withstand prolonged volatility.

Only last month, Michael Saylor predicted that Bitcoin would reach $150,000 before the end of the year. He doubled down on his long-term optimism even as sentiment across the crypto market turned sharply negative.

His bold forecast came in the direct aftermath of one of crypto's worst weekends in years. Last month, a sudden sell-off triggered $19 billion in liquidations across exchanges, sending shockwaves through leveraged traders and institutional investors alike.‚Äã

For now, Strategy remains closely tied to Bitcoin's volatility, with its fortunes fluctuating in tandem with its price.

The latest offering strengthens its Bitcoin position but also highlights the ongoing question of how sustainable Saylor's long-term strategy will be in an increasingly unpredictable market.

Read original story Michael Saylor Isn't Backing Down ‚Äî Even as Bitcoin and MSTR Sink by Camila Grigera Na√≥n at beincrypto.com

Title: Ethereum Ends the Week Strong, but Not Strong Enough to Avoid a 5% Drawdown
Description:
Oops, something went wrong

Ethereum's speed and transaction costs have been a pain in the side of investors for years.

An upcoming upgrade intends to at least partially solve for some of these core issues.

In the meantime, worries around market share gains or losses have some investors on the sidelines willing to wait it out.

10 stocks we like better than Ethereum ‚Ä∫

Ethereum (CRYPTO: ETH) tokens are on the move today, up more than 2.4% over the past 24 hours (as of 2:20 p.m. ET), as the broader cryptocurrency market recovers.

However, on a one week-basis (from 4 p.m. last Friday), this token is actually down 5%. That shouldn't be a surprise to most investors, considering the overall market capitalization of the entire sector dropped 6.2% over the same time frame.

Now, one could look at those numbers and surmise that Ethereum has actually been an outperformer over the past week, an argument I'd hold is likely true. But let's dive into this weekly volatility, and see what investors are making about Ethereum's long-term growth prospects, judging by this price action right now.

One of the more intriguing theses I've seen float around over the past week depicts a world in which Ethereum may give up market share to other blockchains. This thesis is based on the idea that other blockchains are simply faster and more efficient.

It's really that simple.

Ethereum's long transaction times, and at times high gas fees and transaction costs, have led to market share gains among up-and-coming proof-of-stake platforms out there. Ethereum has sought to fix this trend by implementing its latest upgrade, named Fusaka, which will allow for more compressed data to be stored on Ethereum blocks, improving transaction speed and costs over time.

Of course, we'll have to see if this upgrade provides the all-encompassing fix investors are hoping for, and if the sort of real-world asset tokenization and other projects that could come as a result of this upgrade flourish.

But in the midst of uncertainty, investors appear to be selling first and asking questions later. My take is that if sentiment improves, these trends could reverse (potentially in a violent way), but time will be the judge.

For now, Ethereum's weekly volatility is something I think investors ought to pay attention to. I'm waiting for a breakout, but I'm also thinking I may need to wait a bit longer.

Before you buy stock in Ethereum, consider this:

The Motley Fool Stock Advisor analyst team just identified what they believe are the 10 best stocks for investors to buy now‚Ä¶ and Ethereum wasn't one of them. The 10 stocks that made the cut could produce monster returns in the coming years.

Consider when Netflix made this list on December 17, 2004... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $591,613!* Or when Nvidia made this list on April 15, 2005... if you invested $1,000 at the time of our recommendation, you'd have $1,152,905!*

Now, it's worth noting Stock Advisor's total average return is 1,034% ‚Äî a market-crushing outperformance compared to 191% for the S&P 500. Don't miss the latest top 10 list, available with Stock Advisor, and join an investing community built by individual investors for individual investors.

Title: Common acne drug may protect against schizophrenia
Description:
A widely used antibiotic may help lower the chances of some young people developing schizophrenia, according to new research.

Scientists found that adolescents receiving mental health care who were prescribed the antibiotic doxycycline were significantly less likely to develop schizophrenia later in life than those treated with other antibiotics.

Experts believe the results suggest a potential new use for an existing and widely available medication as a preventive treatment for severe mental illness.

Understanding Schizophrenia and Its Early Onset

Schizophrenia is a serious mental health disorder that typically begins in early adulthood and is often marked by hallucinations, delusions, and disorganized thinking. Finding ways to reduce the risk of developing the condition has long been a major challenge for mental health researchers.

To explore possible prevention strategies, scientists from the University of Edinburgh, working with colleagues from the University of Oulu and University College Dublin, analyzed extensive healthcare data from Finland using advanced statistical models.

The study examined health records from more than 56,000 adolescents who had received antibiotics while attending mental health services. Those treated with doxycycline showed a 30-35 percent lower risk of later developing schizophrenia compared with peers who received other types of antibiotics.

The research team believes this protective effect could be related to doxycycline's impact on inflammation and brain development.

How Doxycycline Might Protect the Brain

Doxycycline is a broad-spectrum antibiotic commonly prescribed for infections and acne. Earlier studies have found that it can reduce inflammation in brain cells and affect synaptic pruning -- a normal developmental process in which the brain trims and strengthens neural connections. Too much pruning has been linked to the onset of schizophrenia.

Further analysis confirmed that the reduced risk was not merely due to participants being treated for acne instead of infections and was unlikely to result from other unnoticed differences between the groups.

Professor Ian Kelleher, study lead and Professor of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry at the University of Edinburgh, explained: "As many as half of the people who develop schizophrenia had previously attended child and adolescent mental health services for other mental health problems. At present, though, we don't have any interventions that are known to reduce the risk of going on to develop schizophrenia in these young people. That makes these findings exciting."

He added: "Because the study was observational in nature and not a randomized controlled trial, it means we can't draw firm conclusions on causality, but this is an important signal to further investigate the protective effect of doxycycline and other anti-inflammatory treatments in adolescent psychiatry patients as a way to potentially reduce the risk of developing severe mental illness in adulthood."

The study was published in the American Journal of Psychiatry and involved researchers from the University of Edinburgh, University of Oulu, University College Dublin, and St John of God Hospitaller Services Group. Funding was provided by the Health Research Board.

Title: Stabilizing high-efficiency perovskite solar cells via strategic interfacial contact engineering
Description:
